title: Self-supervised learning for aflatoxin B1 detection using masked spectra
excerpt: Aflatoxins are highly toxic secondary metabolites widely found in peanut and maize kernels. This study proposes a strategy based on self-supervised learning (SSL) for the accurate detection of Aflatoxin B1 in peanuts and maize. Firstly, an SSL backbone network was constructed to perform a spectral reconstruction task on masked spectra, providing pre-trained weights for subsequent supervised learning. Secondly, the spectral reconstruction error was innovatively used as a wavelength attention mechanism, integrated with the fine-tuned encoder from the SSL stage to develop a classification model. This model achieved a mean accuracy of 0.9805 ± 0.0019 in peanuts and 0.9478 ± 0.0060 in maize, outperforming other deep learning models. Furthermore, key wavelengths were selected based on the spectral reconstruction error. Experimental results demonstrated that the 40 selected key wavelengths outperformed other methods, with a more uniform distribution, capturing richer spectral features. The strategy in this study provides an efficient solution for few-sample spectral detection.
summary: Aflatoxin B1, a toxic compound produced by certain moulds, accumulates in peanut and maize kernels and poses significant food safety risks. This paper develops a detection method using self-supervised learning on spectral data—a machine learning approach where a neural network first learns patterns from unlabeled spectral measurements by reconstructing masked portions of spectra, then applies this knowledge to classify whether aflatoxin B1 is present. The method achieved detection accuracy of 98.05 per cent in peanuts and 94.78 per cent in maize, surpassing other deep learning approaches tested. The researchers identified 40 key wavelengths of light that carry the most diagnostic information about aflatoxin presence, selected through analysis of reconstruction errors from the self-supervised stage.  The detection apparatus itself—spectral measurement of grain kernels—operates at the intersection of agricultural commodity flows and toxin surveillance. Aflatoxin B1 emerges here not merely as a pathogenic metabolite requiring elimination, but as a detectable material signature embedded in grain destined for human and animal consumption. The method's efficiency with limited training samples suggests potential deployment in contexts where grain testing infrastructure remains sparse or where rapid screening of high-volume commodity batches is economically necessary. Yet the technology's capacity to identify contaminated grain also depends on access to spectral scanning equipment and computational resources, making detection itself a distributed capacity shaped by capital investment in agricultural supply chains rather than a neutral technical capability.

title: A comprehensive review of decontamination techniques for mycotoxin control in food: Advancement from conventional to unconventional strategies and the way forward
excerpt: Mycotoxin contamination of food and feed is a lingering issue of the global agro-food industries and a matter of severe socio-economic concern. Several methods have been conventionally employed for mycotoxin decontamination but their efficiency remained low and insufficient due to robustness of mycotoxin structures. In this article, use of unconventional technologies like irradiation, ozonation, cold activated plasma, magnetic nanoparticles, high hydrostatic pressure, pulsed electric fields, pulsed light, natural essential oils and phytochemicals in controlling growth of toxigenic fungi and degrading mycotoxins in various foodstuffs have been reviewed. The efficacy of decontamination of different types of major mycotoxins by these novel techniques and the associated safety and limitation factors have been analysed and discussed in detail. Combination of different unconventional techniques and impact of techno-economic-environmental aspects associated with these advanced technologies on their adoption and implementation at large scale to achieve a green and sustainable control of mycotoxins have been highlighted.
summary: This paper surveys decontamination methods for mycotoxins in food and feed, comparing conventional approaches with emerging technologies. The conventional techniques addressed in this review have proven inadequate because mycotoxin molecules are structurally resistant to degradation. The unconventional technologies examined include irradiation, ozonation, cold activated plasma, magnetic nanoparticles, high hydrostatic pressure, pulsed electric fields, pulsed light, natural essential oils, and phytochemicals—all evaluated for their capacity to inhibit toxigenic fungi growth and break down mycotoxins across different food commodities. This paper analyzes the effectiveness of these novel techniques against major mycotoxin types, alongside their safety profiles and practical limitations. The review also considers combinations of multiple unconventional techniques and assesses the technical, economic, and environmental factors that determine whether these advanced technologies can be scaled up for large-scale implementation.  Within food systems shaped by global trade and storage infrastructure, mycotoxin contamination emerges as both a persistent hazard requiring technological intervention and a site where novel decontamination methods generate new dependencies and costs. The shift from conventional to unconventional technologies—from simple physical removal to plasma activation and nanoparticle deployment—reveals how food safety increasingly depends on energy-intensive, capital-heavy systems whose adoption remains uneven across regions and commodity chains. The paper's attention to techno-economic-environmental trade-offs suggests that no single decontamination method resolves the underlying material problem; instead, the choice of technique redistributes risk and resource demand across different stages of production and storage.

title: Advances in affinity magnetic bead - based pretreatment and detection strategies for mycotoxins in foods: A review
excerpt: Food contamination with mycotoxins poses a serious threat to human and animal health. Traditional chromatographic methods and rapid detection techniques are widely used for accurate quantification and on-site rapid screening, respectively, and play essential roles in food safety monitoring. However, these approaches still face limitations arising from cumbersome sample pretreatment and matrix effects. Affinity magnetic beads (AMBs), which integrate highly specific recognition elements with magnetic carriers, represent a promising solution owing to their strong enrichment capability, good dispersibility, soften matrix effects, and high compatibility with automated systems. This review discusses the structure, working principles, and applications of AMBs employing antibodies, aptamers, and molecularly imprinted polymers as recognition elements. It also evaluates their effectiveness in enhancing the sensitivity and accuracy of both chromatographic and rapid detection methods. Finally, the review highlights current challenges and future perspectives for the application of AMBs in mycotoxin detection.
summary: This review examines affinity magnetic beads as tools for detecting mycotoxins in food. The beads work by combining recognition molecules—antibodies, aptamers, or molecularly imprinted polymers—with magnetic carriers to isolate and concentrate mycotoxins from food samples. According to this paper, affinity magnetic beads address persistent problems in mycotoxin detection: they reduce the labour-intensive sample preparation steps that precede analysis, diminish interference from other food components, and integrate readily with automated detection systems. The review evaluates how these beads enhance both traditional chromatographic methods and rapid on-site screening techniques, assessing their capacity to improve detection sensitivity and accuracy across different recognition chemistries.  Within food systems shaped by storage conditions, labour constraints, and capital investment in safety infrastructure, affinity magnetic beads represent a technical intervention that simultaneously reveals and obscures the material conditions of contamination. The beads make mycotoxin detection faster and more automated, yet this efficiency depends on their ability to selectively bind and remove toxins that accumulate precisely because of the economic pressures—inadequate storage facilities, moisture control, and supply chain monitoring—that characterize food production in many regions. Detection technology thus becomes a proxy for managing risk rather than addressing the structural vulnerabilities that allow fungal proliferation and toxin accumulation in the first place.

title: Molecular stabilizing a glucose oxidase from Aspergillus eucalypticola with improved catalytic activity and optimized antimicrobial capacity
source: ScienceDirect Publication: International Journal of Biological Macromolecules
excerpt: Glucose oxidase (GOX EC.1.1.3.4) specifically catalyzes the reaction of β-d-glucose to gluconic acid in an oxygen-consuming process, enabling its antimicrobial potential. However, the unstable nature and insufficient activity of the FAD-dependent dimer hinder the antibacterial capacity. In this study, A GOX from Aspergillus eucalypticola (AeGOXL), outstanding for its catalytic efficiency, was selected for laboratory evolution through random mutagenesis. Three thermostable variants Q148K, H283Y, and P514K were selected and form the combined variant Q148K/H283Y (M1), superior in both thermostability (T50 increased 13 °C, Tm increased 6.7 °C, and 2.1-fold of t1/2 prolonged at 80 °C) and catalytic activity (97% and 57% increase in specific activity and kcat/Km), comparing with the WT. Structural investigations elucidated the molecular stabilization due to additional hydrogen bond network formation, while long-range interaction elevated the flexibility of key residues, improving the substrate affinity. For antibacterial capacity, M1 significantly brought down the half maximal inhibitory concentrations (IC50) for Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli separately to 21.3 and 17.4 mg/L (52.5% and 70.5% lower than the WT, comparable to sensitive conventional antibiotics), in accordance with the electron microscope manifestation. This research delved into the GOX functional based enzymatic antibacterial approaches, providing milder and more eco-friendly substrate to address antibacterial requirements.
summary: Glucose oxidase extracted from Aspergillus eucalypticola was engineered through random mutagenesis to improve its stability and antimicrobial performance. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of glucose to gluconic acid in an oxygen-dependent reaction. A combined variant carrying three mutations (Q148K/H283Y, designated M1) demonstrated superior thermal stability—with a 13 degree Celsius increase in the temperature at which half the enzyme denatures, a 6.7 degree Celsius increase in melting temperature, and a 2.1-fold extension of half-life at 80 degrees Celsius—alongside a 97 percent increase in specific activity and a 57 percent increase in catalytic efficiency compared to the unmodified enzyme. Structural analysis revealed that the mutations created additional hydrogen bonding networks and altered the flexibility of critical amino acid positions, enhancing how effectively the enzyme binds its growth medium. The engineered variant reduced the concentration required to inhibit growth of Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli to 21.3 and 17.4 milligrams per litre respectively—52.5 percent and 70.5 percent lower than the unmodified enzyme—with potency comparable to conventional antibiotics, as confirmed by electron microscopy.  The stabilization of this fungal enzyme reveals a material entanglement characteristic of antimicrobial development in the Anthropocene: the same organism engineered for antibacterial capacity depends on molecular modifications that alter its fundamental biochemistry, creating a tool whose efficacy is inseparable from its engineered fragility. This research positions enzymatic antimicrobial approaches as alternatives to synthetic antibiotics, yet the requirement for laboratory evolution and structural intervention to achieve clinical-level potency underscores how microbial remediation strategies remain bound to the technological and metabolic infrastructures they purport to replace.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest decay in tomatoes, reducing shelf life and creating food safety risks. This paper developed a natural control strategy using essential oil extracted from Ligusticum jeholense through an optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted extraction method, which produced 3.38 times more oil than conventional extraction techniques. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry confirmed the chemical composition remained consistent across production batches. The essential oil demonstrated strong antifungal activity against A. alternata in laboratory conditions (with a concentration needed to inhibit 50 percent of fungal growth at 0.0718 microliters per milliliter), and when applied to tomato fruit, it reduced the size of decay lesions and lowered levels of two mycotoxins produced by the fungus: alternariol and tenuazonic acid. Scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, protein analysis, and physiological measurements showed the essential oil worked through multiple mechanisms—damaging the fungal cell membrane, disrupting energy production, and triggering oxidative stress—and toxicity testing in mice confirmed its safety for use.  Within postharvest tomato storage, the essential oil emerges as both a remediation technology and a material dependency. The fungus itself—capable of rapid adaptation and toxin production under the stresses of storage conditions—becomes simultaneously a threat to commodity value and a driver of the demand for botanical interventions. The extraction method's efficiency gain (3.38-fold yield improvement) reveals how intensified control strategies depend on optimized material processing, embedding agricultural preservation within broader patterns of resource extraction and chemical intensification, even as the intervention is marketed as natural and eco-friendly.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: A hyperglycemic condition, characterized by high glucose concentration in the bloodstream, is one of the most potent dietary risk factors for colorectal cancer (CRC). It regulates the response to oxidative stress, migration, and invasion of CRC cells, as well as affects the integrity of the intestinal barrier, which plays a pivotal role in protecting against chemicals and contaminants present in the diet. Although the molecular mechanisms underlying the toxicity of the mycotoxins deoxynivalenol (DON) and alternariol (AOH) are quite well-known, no research so far has considered the possibility that high glucose concentration might affect the response of CRC cells to mycotoxins. In this study, we evaluated how high glucose condition (50 mmol/L) modulates the effect of two mycotoxins distinct in toxicity and underlying mechanisms: DON (0.1–1 μmol/L) and AOH (0.1–20 μmol/L). We evaluated the migration and invasion in Caco-2 and HT-29 CRC cell lines, impact on barrier integrity and metabolism of mycotoxins in an intestinal in vitro co-culture model comprising Caco-2/HT-29-MTX-E12/CCD-18Co. Our results showed that high glucose concentration indeed modulates the response of CRC cells to mycotoxins, affecting their metabolism and altering the cellular sensitivity towards them. This observation shed new light on the importance of the involvement of different physiological and pathological conditions when considering the toxicity of mycotoxins. • AOH and DON modulate glucose receptors expression in CRC cells. • AOH and DON affect the migration and invasiveness of CRC cells. • High glucose modulates the effect of AOH and DON on CRC invasiveness. • High glucose increases AOH and DON- modulated intestinal integrity. • High glucose affects AOH metabolism as well as AOH and DON recovery.
summary: This paper evaluated how elevated blood glucose concentration alters colon cancer cell responses to two fungal toxins: deoxynivalenol and alternariol. The study exposed two colon cancer cell lines (Caco-2 and HT-29) to high glucose conditions (50 millimoles per litre) combined with deoxynivalenol (0.1–1 micromoles per litre) or alternariol (0.1–20 micromoles per litre), measuring changes in cell migration, invasion, and barrier function. The toxins modulated expression of glucose receptors on cancer cells and altered their invasive behaviour. High glucose conditions changed how cancer cells responded to both mycotoxins, affecting cellular sensitivity and the rate at which cells metabolized alternariol. The study also demonstrated that elevated glucose increased intestinal barrier integrity in the presence of these toxins, contrary to what might be expected from glucose's known role as a cancer risk factor.  Within the material assemblages of the human gut, hyperglycemia and fungal toxins do not act as independent threats but rather as co-constitutive forces that reshape cellular vulnerability and metabolic capacity. The finding that high glucose simultaneously increases barrier protection while modulating cancer cell invasiveness reveals the contradictory material logic of metabolic dysregulation—a condition that accelerates cancer risk through one pathway while triggering compensatory responses through another. This suggests that the toxicological profile of mycotoxins cannot be isolated from the physiological states they encounter; their effects emerge from the specific metabolic terrain they inhabit, one increasingly shaped by industrial food systems that deliver both refined carbohydrates and fungal contaminants to the same vulnerable tissues.

title: A Novel Versatile Neopullulanase with Transglycosylation Activity from Bacillus Inaquosorum: Heterologous Expression, Characterization, and Synergistic Application with α-Transglucosidase from Aspergillus niger in Bread Making

excerpt: To explore transglycosidase application potential in starch processing and baking, a Bacillus inaquosorum strain with high amylopectin debranching activity was isolated and identified from the soil. This paper cloned the bacterium's neopullulanase gene and produced the enzyme in laboratory *Escherichia coli* cultures. The recombinant enzyme required metal ions to function, worked optimally at 35 degrees Celsius and neutral pH, and specifically cleaved the branching bonds in starch. When combined with an enzyme from the mould *Aspergillus niger*, the two enzymes worked combined-effect: adding both enzymes at 1000 units per kilogram of wheat flour improved bread volume, texture firmness, and shelf stability. The mixed enzymes altered the physical structure of dough by reducing starch crystallinity to 14.5 percent and lowering the energy required for starch gelatinization to 3.95 millijoules per milligram.  Within industrial bread production, this research documents the material entanglement between bacterial and fungal enzymatic labour—two organisms from radically different ecological niches now coordinated to transform starch structure and extend product shelf life. The combined-effect effect reveals how microbial metabolic capacities become economically valuable not in isolation but through deliberate pairing, turning soil microbes into precision tools for manipulating the physical properties of a staple carbohydrate. This points to a broader pattern in food biotechnology where the same organisms isolated from soil or fermentation vessels are redeployed as industrial inputs, their metabolic versatility captured and standardized for commodity production.

summary: A 66-year-old man presented with blurred vision caused by cytomegalovirus retinitis, accompanied by severely depleted CD4+ T-cell counts (102 cells per microliter) and high levels of cytomegalovirus genetic material in blood and eye fluid. Initial treatment with ganciclovir produced temporary improvement, but the retinal infection recurred five months later alongside new lung nodules. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing of fluid obtained from bronchoscopy identified two simultaneous pulmonary infections: Tropheryma whipplei and Penicillium digitatum, organisms that conventional laboratory testing had failed to detect. The patient's profound immunosuppression and this specific combination of infections—cytomegalovirus retinitis together with pulmonary co-infection by these two organisms—prompted investigation that revealed Epstein–Barr virus-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, an aggressive blood cancer that had remained undiagnosed until these opportunistic infections surfaced.  The clinical sequence documented in this case illustrates how a single malignancy can orchestrate multiple simultaneous microbial invasions across different body sites. The lymphoma's disruption of immune function created conditions permitting not just one but two fungal and bacterial pathogens to establish pulmonary infection, while simultaneously enabling cytomegalovirus to breach the eye—a pattern that reveals the material entanglement between malignant human cells and opportunistic microorganisms. What appears clinically as separate infections is, in this instance, a unified phenomenon rooted in the cancer's capacity to unmake the body's defenses, transforming the patient into a growth medium where multiple microbial species can flourish in concert.

title: Fungal diagnostic stewardship in immunocompromised populations: a focus on molds and dimorphic fungi
source: American Society for Microbiology: Clinical Microbiology Reviews: Table of Contents
excerpt: SUMMARY Invasive fungal diseases cause severe illness and death in immunocompromised patients. Antifungal use is increasingly common, as is fungal diagnostic testing. However, these efforts have not been guided by traditional stewardship efforts akin to those used for bacterial infections. Fungal diagnostic stewardship can have a significant impact on the care of vulnerable patients, including decreasing unnecessary testing while increasing appropriate testing and improving testing strategies to reduce diagnostic errors. In this review, we discuss the most frequently used fungal diagnostic assays for molds and dimorphic fungal infections, their diagnostic performance for these organisms in immunocompromised hosts, and strategies to improve diagnostic stewardship and ultimately patient outcomes.
summary: This paper reviews diagnostic approaches for fungal infections caused by molds and dimorphic fungi in immune-weakened patients. The authors examine the most commonly used diagnostic assays for detecting these organisms, evaluate their performance in immune-weakened hosts, and identify gaps in how diagnostic testing is currently managed. The paper notes that while antifungal medications and fungal diagnostic testing have become increasingly widespread, these clinical practices have not been subject to the same systematic stewardship frameworks that guide bacterial infection management. The authors argue that implementing fungal diagnostic stewardship—by reducing unnecessary testing, improving test selection, and refining diagnostic strategies—could decrease diagnostic errors and ultimately improve outcomes for vulnerable patients.  Within the context of the Patchy Anthropocene, this diagnostic stewardship framework reveals a critical tension: the same fungi that threaten immune-weakened bodies also drive the expansion of testing infrastructure, antifungal markets, and clinical protocols. Diagnostic uncertainty around molds and dimorphic fungi—organisms that colonize both clinical specimens and hospital environments—creates dependencies on increasingly sophisticated detection methods, which in turn shape patterns of treatment and pharmaceutical use. The paper's focus on stewardship in immune-weakened populations documents how fungal pathogens become sites where clinical vulnerability, diagnostic technology, and pharmaceutical intervention become materially entangled, with the capacity to both harm and to generate new forms of medical authority and economic activity.

summary: This paper presents a multicenter diagnostic study of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in non-neutropenic patients, integrating fungal load measurement with clinical risk assessment. The study enrolled 238 non-neutropenic adults with suspected infection across three tertiary hospitals between December 2020 and December 2024, identifying 134 confirmed cases and 104 non-cases. The researchers used targeted next-generation sequencing of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid—the fluid obtained by bronchoscopy from the lower airways—to quantify Aspergillus genetic material, stratifying results into low, medium, and high tiers. Patients with confirmed invasive pulmonary aspergillosis showed elevated rates of diabetes (73.9%) and corticosteroid use compared to those without infection. The study built a multivariable logistic regression model incorporating clinical, radiological, and microbiological variables, validated through internal resampling methods, and assessed diagnostic accuracy using receiver operating characteristic analysis.  The findings reveal how a respiratory infection diagnosis becomes entangled with markers of metabolic and immunological vulnerability—diabetes and corticosteroid dependency—that reflect broader patterns of chronic disease management and pharmaceutical exposure in hospital populations. The shift from qualitative pathogen detection to quantified fungal load creates a new diagnostic object: the stratified Aspergillus measure becomes simultaneously a clinical threshold and a site where host fragility and microbial abundance are rendered commensurable, collapsing the distinction between what constitutes infection risk and what constitutes infection itself.

title: An unintended consequence: a review of iatrogenic central nervous system mold infections and outbreaks
source: American Society for Microbiology: Clinical Microbiology Reviews: Table of Contents
excerpt: SUMMARY Iatrogenic central nervous system mold infections (ICNSMIs) are rare and occur as sporadic complications of neurosurgical procedures or device insertions. However, recent outbreaks have been reported in outpatient settings, following epidural injections with contaminated medicines. We conducted a comprehensive literature review of studies published without date restrictions through July 2025 on ICNSMIs. We identified 905 cases of such infections, with 4% occurring in non-outbreak settings and 96% associated with five documented outbreaks. In both non-outbreak and outbreak settings, infections were more common after spinal/epidural injections, with contaminated medicines or supplies being the primary source. Due to their angioinvasive tendencies, ICNSMI caused by Fusarium solani and Aspergillus species had a higher frequency of stroke/intracranial hemorrhage ( P = 0.011), aneurysm formation ( P = 0.012), and resulted in higher mortality compared with ICNSMI caused by other molds ( P < 0.001). ICNSMI, as a result of catheter-associated fungemia, was very rare (only one case). Strategies to identify ICNSMI in exposed individuals during an outbreak have included (i) symptom-driven lumbar puncture, (ii) screening lumbar puncture regardless of symptoms, and (iii) screening brain MRI regardless of symptoms. Measurement of (1→3)-β-D-glucan in cerebrospinal fluid was a valuable tool to diagnose ICNSMI preemptively. Outcomes of ICNSMI following neurosurgical procedures were poor (90-day mortality of 35%) and depended on the route of inoculation, mold species, timing of diagnosis, and prompt initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy in combination with source control. Patients with ICNSMI often suffered long-term neurologic sequelae, even with the most optimal management strategies.
summary: Iatrogenic central nervous system mold infections occur predominantly in outbreak settings, with this paper identifying 905 documented cases across the literature, of which 96% were associated with five major outbreaks and only 4% occurred sporadically. The infections resulted from contaminated medicines or medical supplies introduced during spinal and epidural injections rather than from catheter-associated fungemia, which accounted for only a single case. Fusarium solani and Aspergillus species demonstrated higher angioinvasive capacity than other molds, leading to significantly elevated rates of stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, and aneurysm formation, alongside substantially higher mortality. Measurement of a fungal cell wall component in cerebrospinal fluid proved effective for early diagnosis, and outcomes depended critically on the mold species involved, timing of diagnosis, and rapid initiation of antifungal treatment combined with source control, though 90-day mortality following neurosurgical procedures reached 35% and survivors frequently experienced lasting neurological damage.  These outbreaks reveal how medical interventions designed to relieve pain or treat neurological conditions become vectors for mold colonization when supply chains fail—a pattern shaped by the material vulnerabilities of injectable medicines and the difficulty of maintaining sterility across distributed outpatient networks. The same Aspergillus and Fusarium species that pose clinical threats also expose the fragility of contemporary medical infrastructure; their capacity to invade blood vessels and cause hemorrhage within the nervous system transforms a contamination event into a cascade of vascular rupture and tissue death, making outbreak response dependent not only on clinical vigilance but on the ability to trace contaminated batches backward through supply chains and forward into exposed populations.

title: Contribution of terrestrial processes in reducing environmental mycotoxin levels: a review on mycotoxin-soil interactions
excerpt: Mycotoxins are fungal metabolites that can harm humans and animals. They occur primarily in infected crops, with higher levels under environmental stress. Their origin in contaminated crops is the main contributor to soil contamination. Although high levels can be detected in soils, these are transitory and in average far lower than in contaminated crops, indicating a key role of functioning soils in down-regulating environmental mycotoxin levels. This review examines mycotoxin-soil interactions in terms of four terrestrial processes: (i) adsorption to soil fractions, (ii) microbial transformation and mineralisation (iii) transport/mobilization with water, (iv) plant uptake and response. This aligns with incubation studies suggesting a key role of bacteria in the degradation of mycotoxins. This path is favoured by the availability of the mycotoxins, that can be reduced by the adsorption to soil particles: the aromatic character and the carbonyl functions are decisive for adsorption to soil organic matter and clay particles, respectively. Consequently, mycotoxin levels in environmental compartments can be interpreted as the (net) result of entry and dissipation processes mediated through the soil, rather than the soil acting as a source of them. Plant uptake represents a minor pathway of contamination compared to the in situ production. In soil-plant systems, suboptimal nitrogen (N) and pesticide management are factors triggering fungal infestation and mycotoxins levels. Fungal infestation and mycotoxin can induce the polyphenolic response of the plant, along with mycotoxin metabolization as reported for DON. summary: Soils function as active filters that reduce environmental mycotoxin levels rather than amplifying them, according to this review. The paper identifies four terrestrial processes mediating mycotoxin fate: binding to soil particles, microbial breakdown and complete mineralization, movement through water, and uptake by plants. Microbial degradation emerges as the dominant dissipation pathway, with bacterial activity playing a central role—a process enhanced by greater microbial biomass and a narrow ratio of fungi to bacteria in the soil community. The chemical structure of mycotoxins determines their behavior: aromatic compounds bind preferentially to soil organic matter, while those containing carbonyl groups attach to clay particles, reducing their availability for further transport or uptake. Plant uptake of mycotoxins from soil represents a minor contamination route compared to direct fungal infection of crops during growth.  Environmental mycotoxin levels thus reflect a balance between entry from contaminated crops and active removal through soil processes, not soil as a source of toxins. Under conditions of suboptimal nitrogen management and pesticide use, plants become more susceptible to fungal infection and mycotoxin accumulation, yet simultaneously mount defensive responses—including the production of protective compounds and metabolic transformation of some mycotoxins like deoxynivalenol. This reveals soil not as inert growth medium but as a working system where microbial communities and plant physiology together regulate the fate of fungal poisons, with implications for how agricultural intensification and climate pressures reshape these mediating relationships.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. summary: Severe burn patients with damaged skin and impaired immune function frequently develop invasive mold infections, yet diagnostic criteria designed for other patient populations do not reliably identify these infections in this group. This paper evaluated how different diagnostic methods—direct microscopy of tissue samples, fungal culture from respiratory secretions and skin biopsies, species-specific genetic detection in blood and tissue samples, and serum galactomannan testing—performed in 276 burn patients admitted between 2014 and 2023 with burns covering at least 15 percent of total body surface area. Among 6,184 samples tested, 489 were positive for mold; skin biopsies yielded 281 positive results while blood tests detected 132 positive results. Ninety-three patients (33.7 percent) showed at least one positive diagnostic criterion, with Aspergillus detected in 25.7 percent of patients, Mucorales in 10.9 percent, and Fusarium in 9.8 percent. Patient mortality increased sharply with the number of positive diagnostic criteria detected: 12.7 percent mortality with no positive criteria, 10.7 percent with one or two criteria, 27.3 percent with three or four criteria, and 46.7 percent with five or more criteria. The paper notes that genetic detection in blood was most sensitive for Mucorales (81.3 percent of cases with skin involvement), moderately sensitive for Aspergillus (40 percent), and least sensitive for Fusarium (15.4 percent).  Within burn units, molds simultaneously mark clinical deterioration and reveal the material vulnerabilities of severely injured bodies—the compromised skin barrier and suppressed immune response create conditions where multiple mold species can establish simultaneous infections. The escalating mortality tied to cumulative positive diagnostic criteria suggests that the presence of multiple molds is not incidental but constitutive of a particular state of bodily breakdown in which burn injury has created a permissive growth medium for fungal colonization. The diagnostic challenge documented here reflects a deeper entanglement: the same diagnostic tools designed to detect pathogenic molds in other contexts must be recalibrated for burn patients, where the ecology of infection is fundamentally altered by trauma and where clinical outcomes depend not on detecting a single pathogen but on recognizing the assemblage of multiple fungal species that exploit the same damaged tissues.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Abstract BACKGROUND Aflatoxin B 1 (AFB 1 ), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa , exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB 1 ‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB 1 . RESULTS A total of 720 broilers (eight replicates of 15 birds each per treatment) were fed a basal diet, an AFB₁‐contaminated diet (1 mg kg −1 ), or AFB 1 diets supplemented with CUR (100, 300, or 500 mg kg −1 ) for 42 days. AFB 1 exposure significantly reduced average daily gain and increased feed conversion ratio ( P < 0.05), whereas CUR supplementation – particularly 300–500 mg kg −1 – improved growth performance relative to the AFB 1 group ( P < 0.05). CUR also decreased serum alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase activities, alleviated hepatic histopathological damage, enhanced hepatic antioxidant enzyme activities (superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase), and suppressed malondialdehyde accumulation ( P < 0.01). At the molecular level, CUR upregulated Nrf2 and its downstream antioxidant genes while downregulating NOD‐like receptor protein 3 (NLRP3), caspase‐1, and interleukin‐1β, indicating attenuation of inflammasome activation and pyroptosis. CONCLUSION Dietary curcumin effectively mitigated AFB 1 ‐induced hepatotoxicity and performance loss in broilers through activation of the Nrf2 antioxidant pathway and inhibition of the NLRP3 inflammasome. These findings highlight CUR as a promising natural feed additive for protecting poultry against mycotoxin‐induced oxidative and inflammatory damage. © 2025 Society of Chemical Industry.
summary: Aflatoxin B1, a mycotoxin commonly found in poorly stored poultry feed, damages broiler livers by triggering oxidative stress and inflammation, reducing weight gain and worsening feed conversion efficiency. This paper tested whether curcumin, a plant compound from turmeric with known antioxidant properties, could protect broilers from this toxin. Over 42 days, 720 broilers received either standard feed, feed contaminated with aflatoxin B1 at 1 milligram per kilogram, or contaminated feed supplemented with curcumin at 100, 300, or 500 milligrams per kilogram. Aflatoxin B1 alone reduced daily weight gain and increased the amount of feed needed per unit of growth; curcumin at 300–500 milligrams per kilogram reversed these effects. At the tissue level, curcumin lowered liver enzyme markers of damage, reduced scarring and cell death in liver tissue, boosted protective enzymes like superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase, and reduced harmful oxidative byproducts. Molecularly, curcumin activated the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 antioxidant pathway and suppressed the NOD-like receptor protein 3 inflammasome—a cellular trigger for inflammatory cell death—by reducing caspase-1 and interleukin-1 beta.  Within contaminated feed systems, curcumin emerges as both a remedial intervention and a marker of deeper structural vulnerabilities. The same storage failures that generate aflatoxin B1 as a byproduct of mould growth in feed warehouses create the conditions requiring chemical mitigation; curcumin does not address the material conditions—moisture, temperature, ventilation—that allow toxin-producing moulds to proliferate in the first place. Rather, this paper documents how a natural additive can be layered into industrial poultry production to manage exposure without altering the infrastructural arrangements that make such exposure routine. The efficacy of curcumin thus depends on, and reinforces, a system where mycotoxin contamination is treated as an inevitable cost absorbed through supplementation rather than prevented through transformed storage practices.

title: Antifungal Activity and Resistance Risk of Cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, the Causal Agent of Peanut Root Rot
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Peanut root rot (PRR), caused by Fusarium solani, is a common and destructive disease. Cyclobutrifluram exhibits antifungal activity against Fusarium spp., yet its bioactivity and resistance risk against F. solani remain unclear. In this study, the EC50 values of cyclobutrifluram against 155 F. solani strains ranged from 0.0279 to 0.1102 μg/mL, with a mean of 0.0513 ± 0.0170 μg/mL. Treatment with cyclobutrifluram significantly inhibited conidial production and germination, reduced succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) activity, increased hyphal branching, and shortened the distance between septa or cell nuclei. Cyclobutrifluram provided excellent control over PRR. Seven laboratory-generated cyclobutrifluram-resistant mutants showed no or slight fitness penalties and exhibited positive cross-resistance only with pydiflumetofen, indicating a moderate-to-high resistance risk. Resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani was conferred by four SDH substitutions (FsSdhBH248Y, FsSdhC1A83V, FsSdhC2A85V, and FsSdhDD184G), which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement. This study provides crucial insights for developing effective control strategies to manage PRR.
summary: This paper documents the antifungal potency of cyclobutrifluram against *Fusarium solani*, the fungus responsible for peanut root rot, across 155 field-collected strains. The drug inhibited spore production and germination, disrupted the fungus's energy metabolism by reducing succinate dehydrogenase activity, and altered hyphal structure by increasing branching and compressing the spacing between cell compartments. Cyclobutrifluram delivered effective disease control in peanut crops. However, the study identified a significant liability: seven laboratory-generated resistant mutants emerged without substantial fitness costs and showed cross-resistance to pydiflumetofen, signalling moderate-to-high risk of resistance development in field populations. Genetic analysis pinpointed four specific mutations in the succinate dehydrogenase enzyme complex that confer resistance, confirmed through molecular modelling and experimental gene replacement.  The tension embedded in this finding reflects a familiar pattern in agricultural chemical control: a potent tool for managing crop disease simultaneously creates the conditions for its own obsolescence. The same metabolic target that makes cyclobutrifluram effective—the succinate dehydrogenase complex—proves vulnerable to rapid genetic adaptation in *Fusarium solani*, with resistant mutants bearing no apparent survival cost. This decoupling of resistance from fitness penalty suggests that once resistance emerges in peanut fields, it will persist and spread unchecked, transforming cyclobutrifluram from a solution into a driver of fungal adaptation. The moderate-to-high resistance risk documented here reflects not a flaw in the molecule but a structural feature of intensive monoculture agriculture: the reliance on single-target fungicides in environments where fungal populations are large, genetically diverse, and under constant chemical pressure.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR 34 -mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR 34 /L98H, TR 34 /L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR 34 /L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR 34 /L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.
summary: Aspergillus fumigatus isolates collected in the Netherlands between 1994 and 2022 showed a rising prevalence of azole resistance, with 34 distinct genetic variants identified in the cyp51A gene. This paper examined how individual genetic variations and combinations of variations in this gene affect resistance to four azole antifungal drugs. The researchers used computer modelling to predict how amino acid changes would alter the structure of the Cyp51A protein, then introduced these mutations into laboratory strains using genetic editing technology and measured how resistant the resulting fungi were to azoles. Strains carrying multiple mutations together showed substantially higher resistance levels than unmutated strains, particularly to voriconazole and isavuconazole, though the most heavily mutated strain remained susceptible to itraconazole despite carrying the TR34 resistance marker.  The pattern documented here reveals how a pathogenic fungus generates pharmaceutical resistance not as a binary outcome but as a graduated response shaped by the specific combination of genetic changes present. The same mutations that render this organism clinically intractable in one drug context can leave it vulnerable in another, creating a fragmented landscape of therapeutic options that depends entirely on which particular mutations accumulate in which individual isolate. This conditional resistance—where a single fungal strain's susceptibility profile shifts across the azole drug class—reflects how microbial adaptation to medical intervention produces not uniform danger but distributed and uneven vulnerability, a pattern that will shape clinical decision-making and drug availability differently across different patient populations and treatment contexts.

title: Molecular Dynamics and Quantum Chemical Insights into the Molecular Basis of Differential Toxicity of the Mycotoxin Deoxynivalenol (DON) and Its Microbial Derivatives DOM-1 and 3-epi-DON
source: acs: ACS Omega: Table of Contents

DON binds to site A of the 60S ribosomal subunit in eukaryotes, triggering a ribotoxic stress response. Despite structural similarity, its metabolites, deepoxy-deoxynivalenol (DOM-1) and 3-epi-deoxynivalenol (3-epi-DON), are nontoxic, but the molecular basis of this difference is unclear. summary: Deoxynivalenol, a poisonous compound produced by *Fusarium* fungi that contaminates cereal grains, binds tightly to a specific site on the 60S ribosomal subunit and triggers a cellular stress response in eukaryotes. This paper used computational methods—molecular docking, molecular dynamics simulations lasting 500 nanoseconds, and quantum chemical calculations—to explain why DON causes harm while its chemically similar metabolites, deepoxy-deoxynivalenol and 3-*epi*-deoxynivalenol (3-*epi*-DON), do not. The analysis revealed that DON maintains stable binding to the ribosomal pocket through strong interactions with a magnesium ion and a specific nucleotide, whereas DOM-1 and 3-*epi*-DON cannot sustain these interactions because they lack DON's epoxide group or have altered hydroxyl group positioning, causing them to dissociate from the binding site. The quantum chemical analysis identified electrostatic and induction forces as the primary energetic drivers stabilizing DON at the ribosomal site. Testing in human colon cancer cells confirmed that DOM-1 and 3-*epi*-DON lack toxicity while DON retains its capacity to trigger the ribotoxic stress response, establishing a clear relationship between molecular structure and toxic effect.  The findings document how minor chemical modifications—the presence or absence of a single epoxide group, the spatial orientation of a hydroxyl group—determine whether a trichothecene molecule becomes a cellular poison or an inert metabolite. This structural specificity reveals the material precision required for toxicity, yet simultaneously exposes a vulnerability: the very chemical features that make DON dangerous also define the pathways through which it might be neutralized or transformed. The paper thus maps both the mechanism of harm and, implicitly, the chemical logic by which grain-contaminating fungi and their toxins might be rendered harmless through targeted molecular intervention.

title: Structural Diversification and Biosynthesis of Pesticidal Pyrroline-Derived Alkaloid from Penicillium citrinum SCSIO DF147

excerpt: The pyrroline-derived alkaloid N-(2-methyl-3-oxodec-8-enoyl)-2-pyrroline (MOEP, 1) is a potential pesticide that remains to be structurally diversified for target screening and biosynthesis studies. Bioactivity-guided investigation of the marine-derived fungus Penicillium citrinum SCSIO DF147 yielded five classes of pyrroline-derived alkaloids (1-15), including five new compounds (2-4, 14, and 15). These compounds were first evaluated for chitinase (OfChtII and OfChi-h) inhibition, revealing that both the 3-pyrroline ring and the Δ8',9' double bond are key functional groups. Pesticidal and fungicidal evaluation highlighted compound 1, which outperformed the positive control diflubenzuron against the lepidopteran pest Plutella xylostella, causing 100% larval mortality after 5 days of feeding at 5 mM. The biosynthetic gene cluster (pasA-D) for 1 was identified and characterized. The cytochrome P450 PasB was shown to catalyze the final tailoring step, transforming intermediate 8 into the 3-pyrroline functional group in 1 via dehydroxymethylation and dehydrogenation. These findings provide insights for developing new chitinase-targeting pesticides.
summary: This paper describes the isolation and characterization of pyrroline-derived alkaloids from the marine fungus *Penicillium citrinum* SCSIO DF147. Bioactivity-guided screening yielded fifteen compounds across five structural classes, including five previously unknown compounds. Testing revealed that the 3-pyrroline ring and a specific double bond (Δ8',9') are essential structural features for activity against chitinase enzymes. Compound 1 (N-(2-methyl-3-oxodec-8-enoyl)-2-pyrroline) demonstrated pesticidal potency, killing 100 percent of larvae of the diamondback moth *Plutella xylostella* within five days at 5 millimolar concentration, outperforming the commercial pesticide diflubenzuron. The researchers identified and characterized the biosynthetic gene cluster responsible for producing compound 1, demonstrating that a cytochrome P450 enzyme (PasB) catalyzes the final chemical transformation—converting an intermediate compound into the active 3-pyrroline form through removal of a hydroxymethyl group and addition of a double bond.  Within the material entanglements of marine fungal chemistry and pest control, this paper reveals how a single fungal strain becomes simultaneously a source of bioactive molecules and a site for understanding insecticidal mechanisms. The structural features that make these alkaloids effective against insect chitinase—the very enzyme that allows insects to build their exoskeletons—also mark them as products of fungal metabolic pathways shaped by competition in marine sediments. The optimization of compound 1 for pesticidal use thus depends on understanding not just its target in the insect body, but the fungal enzymatic machinery that evolved to produce it, collapsing the distinction between natural product and synthetic pesticide into a shared biosynthetic logic.

summary: The source abstract describes development of an analytical method to detect 15 different mycotoxins produced by three fungal genera—Fusarium, Alternaria, and Aspergillus—in plant-based meat, cheese, and fish substitutes. This paper adapted ultra-high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry to simultaneously measure these toxins, which include deoxynivalenol and its derivatives, aflatoxins, ochratoxin A, and sterigmatocystin, among others. The method employed a quick, easy, cheap, effective, rugged, and safe extraction approach followed by dispersive solid phase extraction for sample cleanup and stable isotope dilution analysis for quantification. Detection limits ranged from 0.01 micrograms per kilogram for some aflatoxins and sterigmatocystin to 14.1 micrograms per kilogram for deoxynivalenol-3-glucoside, with quantification limits between 0.02 and 41.9 micrograms per kilogram across the 15 toxins measured.  The expansion of plant-based protein markets creates new sites where fungal metabolites accumulate and require monitoring—yet the choice of which toxins to measure, and at what detection thresholds, reflects prior regulatory and commercial decisions rather than comprehensive microbial ecology. This paper's focus on plant-based alternatives reveals a material dependency: as animal agriculture is displaced by crop-based substitutes, the fungal contaminants embedded in grain and legume supply chains become newly visible and newly regulated, shifting but not eliminating exposure pathways shaped by agricultural intensification and global commodity flows.

title: Thermoplastic Molding of Chitosan to Form Living Plastic Materials
source: Wiley: Advanced Materials: Table of Contents
excerpt: Abstract Numerous approaches for the solution‐based fabrication of chitosan‐based materials are reported, but most often result in materials with limitations in terms of stability in aqueous systems and mechanics unless chemical cross‐linking is utilized. In the present study, a thermomechanical compression method is presented for solid‐state processing of chitosan powders into dense bulk plastic‐like materials where the mechanical and physical properties can be tailored. To achieve this outcome, chitosan‐citrate complexes, formed through ionic cross‐linking and amidation, undergo thermal fusion at high temperature and pressure to generate robust materials with retention of the inherent properties of chitosan, including biodegradability and cytocompatibility. The chitosan‐based plastics can be doped with enzymes and antibiotics with retention of bioactivity and are also explored as living materials when microbial cells (e.g., Pseudomonas putida ) are included in the process and subsequently shown to maintain metabolic functions to degrade organic pollutants. This thermoplastic approach for solid‐state processing of chitosan enables the development of a variety of new materials and composites with embedded biomolecules for enhanced functions. This solid‐state fabrication of chitosan bulk materials approach eliminates the need for conventional solution‐based processing, enabling rapid material production via compression molding while reducing costs, minimizing waste, and improving overall manufacturing efficiency.
summary: Chitosan powders can be transformed into dense plastic-like materials through thermomechanical compression—heating and pressing chitosan-citrate complexes at high temperature and pressure to create robust solids that retain the original polymer's biodegradability and capacity to support cell growth. This paper demonstrates that the resulting plastics maintain mechanical and physical properties suitable for practical use without requiring chemical cross-linking agents. The materials can be loaded with enzymes and antibiotics while preserving their biological activity, and when inoculated with bacterial cells such as *Pseudomonas putida*, the embedded microorganisms remain metabolically active and capable of breaking down organic pollutants. The solid-state compression approach reduces manufacturing complexity and waste compared to traditional solution-based methods, enabling faster production at lower cost.  Within the material transformations of the Anthropocene, this work reveals a productive tension: chitosan itself—derived from shellfish waste streams—becomes a plastic substitute that can simultaneously host living degradative capacity. The bacterial cells embedded in the material matrix are neither passive fillers nor contaminants but functional agents whose metabolic labour transforms the composite into a remediation technology. Yet this embedding of microbial work within manufactured solids also represents a new form of biological capture and control, where the capacity of living systems to process pollutants is fixed into industrial form and extracted as a material property rather than emerging from autonomous ecological relations.

title: Prevalence of mycotoxin contamination in different types of tea: a systematic review and meta-analysis
excerpt: The consumption of tea as a beverage is considerably increasing worldwide. However, some questions are raised about its safety, particularly regarding the potential contamination by mycotoxins. Included studies were selected from Scopus, Science Direct, Web of Science, PubMed and Google Scholar research databases, according to PRISMA guidelines. summary: This paper presents a systematic review and meta-analysis of mycotoxin contamination across five types of tea — black, green, dark, white, and pu-erh — drawing on 21 included studies from multiple databases. The analysis found that deoxynivalenol was the most prevalent contaminant at 43.8 percent, followed by ochratoxin A at 29.1 percent, enniatin at 23.7 percent, citrinin at 23.6 percent, zearalenone at 17.8 percent, and aflatoxins at 12.4 percent. The majority of studies (84.6 percent) used high-performance liquid chromatography or liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry for detection. The review compared contamination rates between two periods (2000–2017 and 2018–2022) and examined whether a country's income level influenced contamination prevalence.  Tea consumption is rising globally, yet the material pathway from leaf to cup carries multiple fungal metabolites whose presence reflects uneven exposure to contamination risk. The prevalence of deoxynivalenol and ochratoxin A — compounds produced by field fungi during growth and storage — suggests that tea operates simultaneously as a commodity subject to post-harvest degradation and as a consumed substance whose safety depends on agricultural practices and infrastructure conditions that vary by region and economic capacity. This paper documents not merely a health concern but a material entanglement: the same drying, storage, and transport conditions that preserve tea's market value can also concentrate the metabolic byproducts of moulds, making contamination both a marker of where tea is grown and processed, and a consequence of how it moves through global supply chains.

title: Purpuric targetoid eruption revealing disseminated mucormycosis
source: Wiley: Journal of the European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology: Table of Contents
excerpt: A 76-year-old man with newly diagnosed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma was admitted for chemotherapy with curative intent. During treatment he developed febrile neutropenia and a respiratory infection that rapidly progressed to septic shock. Dermatology was consulted for a 3-day purpuric eruption on the left hemithorax and flank, composed of well-demarcated annular targetoid plaques with central induration and purpuric rims (Figure 1a). In the setting of refractory sepsis despite broad-spectrum antimicrobials, the morphology suggested septic emboli or vasculotropic infection. Punch biopsies from the centre and rim were sent for histopathology, culture and molecular testing and escalation to liposomal amphotericin B was recommended. Histology revealed extensive occlusive angioinvasive fungal thrombi (Figure 1b); PCR identified Mucorales, establishing disseminated mucormycosis, likely from a pulmonary source. This case highlights how recognition of a purpuric targetoid eruption in an immunocompromised, critically ill patient can provide a crucial clue to life-threatening invasive fungal infection. Open access publication funding provided by FCT (b-on). The authors have nothing to report. None declared. Not applicable. The patient in this manuscript has given informed consent to the publication of their clinical images. Data sharing is not applicable to this article as no datasets were generated or analysed during the current study.
summary: A 76-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for newly diagnosed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma developed febrile neutropenia and respiratory infection that progressed to septic shock. A purpuric eruption appeared on the left side of the chest and flank, consisting of well-defined ring-shaped plaques with central hardening and purple borders. Skin biopsies from the centre and edge of the lesions revealed extensive fungal material blocking blood vessels, with molecular testing identifying Mucorales, confirming disseminated mucormycosis originating from the lungs. The patient's critical condition and failure to respond to broad-spectrum antibiotics prompted escalation to liposomal amphotericin B treatment. This paper demonstrates that recognition of purpuric ring-shaped skin eruptions in immune-weakened, critically ill patients can signal life-threatening invasive fungal infection.  The appearance of Mucorales in skin lesions during chemotherapy-induced immune suppression reveals a material entanglement between cancer treatment protocols and fungal invasion pathways. The same conditions that destroy cancer cells—neutropenia, barrier disruption, systemic inflammation—create ecological openings for opportunistic moulds to establish vascular invasion and disseminate from respiratory sites to distant tissues. The purpuric targetoid pattern itself becomes a readable trace of this entanglement: a visible record of where fungal thrombi have blocked blood flow and triggered tissue death, transforming the skin into a diagnostic surface that exposes the hidden metabolic vulnerabilities produced by contemporary oncology practice.

title: Aspergillus Serology Predicts Relapse in Chronic Pulmonary Aspergillosis: Implications for Personalised Follow‐Up Strategies
excerpt: ABSTRACT Introduction Relapses occur in up to 40% of patients after prolonged courses of antifungal treatment for chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA). The factors predisposing to relapse remain poorly defined. Methods We conducted a retrospective study of adults treated for ≥ 6 months with oral azoles for CPA. Patients who completed antifungal therapy and were deemed not to require further treatment were included. Demographic, clinical, radiological and serological data at treatment completion were collected. CPA relapse was defined as symptomatic and radiological deterioration leading to re‐initiation of antifungal therapy. Cox regression and Kaplan–Meier analyses were used to identify predictors of relapse and mortality. Results Among 125 patients (56% male; mean age 61 years), median treatment duration was 36 months. Thirty‐two (26%) developed relapse; relapse rate at 1 year was 16%. Aspergillus sensitisation (specific IgE > 0.35 IU/mL) and elevated Aspergillus ‐specific IgG (> 40 mg/L) at treatment completion were independently associated with relapse ( p < 0.05). No patient with IgG < 40 mg/L relapsed. Underlying lung disease (COPD or prior tuberculosis), extent of radiological involvement, or treatment duration were not significantly associated with relapse or mortality. Conclusions Aspergillus sensitisation and persistently elevated Aspergillus ‐specific IgG at the end of antifungal therapy were independent predictors of CPA relapse. These parameters may reflect ongoing fungal airway burden and can help identify patients requiring extended or closer post‐treatment follow‐up. Underlying comorbidities were not associated with relapse risk.
summary: Aspergillus-specific antibody levels at the end of antifungal treatment predicted relapse in this retrospective study of 125 patients treated for chronic pulmonary aspergillosis. Patients with elevated Aspergillus-specific IgG (above 40 milligrams per litre) at treatment completion had significantly higher relapse rates;  no patient with IgG below this threshold relapsed during follow-up. Aspergillus sensitisation, measured as specific IgE above 0.35 international units per millilitre, was also independently associated with relapse. Among the 125 patients (56 percent male, mean age 61 years) who completed at least six months of oral azole therapy, 32 (26 percent) experienced relapse, with a one-year relapse rate of 16 percent. Median treatment duration was 36 months. Underlying lung disease such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or prior tuberculosis, the extent of radiological involvement, or the length of antifungal treatment were not significantly associated with relapse risk.  The persistent elevation of Aspergillus-specific antibodies after prolonged antifungal treatment suggests a duality in what these serological markers represent: they simultaneously indicate successful immune recognition of the fungus and ongoing fungal presence in the airway. Rather than signalling cure, these antibodies may reflect a material persistence—fungal material or metabolic byproducts continuing to circulate or colonise lung tissue despite months of drug exposure. This finding reveals how the same immunological response that protects against acute infection can become a marker of incomplete clearance, positioning certain patients in a state of precarious stability where relapse becomes not a random event but a predictable consequence of incomplete fungal elimination.

title: Efficacy of Ipflufenoquin against Strawberry Gray Mold: Insights from AlphaFold- Based Structural Modeling and Genome-Wide Transcriptomic Analysis
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea significantly threatens strawberry production. This study evaluated the efficacy of ipflufenoquin, a novel dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) inhibitor, against fungal pathogens isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Ipflufenoquin demonstrated a high in vitro sensitivity to B. cinerea and broad activity against other pathogens. Fruit and greenhouse trials confirmed its robust control of gray mold, including strains resistant to multiple fungicide classes. However, treatment shifted the fungal community, promoting less sensitive genera, such as Cladosporium and Rhizopus. Structural modeling with AlphaFold2 and molecular docking confirmed that ipflufenoquin binds to the quinone binding tunnel of DHODH, correlating binding affinity with susceptibility. Additionally, RNA-seq analysis revealed that ipflufenoquin suppresses primary metabolic pathways while triggering a robust stress response, up-regulating detoxification and efflux transporter genes. This integrated study confirms the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold and elucidates its molecular impacts, offering essential data for sustainable management strategies.
summary: This paper documents the testing of ipflufenoquin, a dihydroorotate dehydrogenase inhibitor, against gray mold fungus (*Botrytis cinerea*) isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Laboratory tests showed the compound was highly effective against the target fungus and demonstrated activity against other fungal pathogens. Trials in fruit and greenhouse settings confirmed robust control of gray mold, including strains that had already developed resistance to multiple classes of existing fungicides. The researchers used AlphaFold2 protein modeling and molecular docking to show that ipflufenoquin binds to a specific site on the dihydroorotate dehydrogenase enzyme, with binding strength correlating to fungal susceptibility. Gene expression analysis revealed that the compound suppresses the fungus's basic metabolic processes while triggering stress responses, including increased activity of detoxification and efflux transporter genes that may contribute to resistance mechanisms.  Yet the treatment revealed an ecological cost embedded in the strawberry production system: controlling *Botrytis cinerea* created space for less sensitive fungal genera including *Cladosporium* and *Rhizopus* to proliferate. This pattern—where a targeted fungicide simultaneously eliminates a threat and reshapes the microbial community toward species that escape the same chemical pressure—illustrates how agricultural interventions operate within entangled systems of pathogen, crop, and capital. The compound's efficacy against resistant strains positions it as economically valuable for growers facing fungicide-resistant populations, yet its deployment appears to redistribute rather than resolve the underlying vulnerability of monoculture strawberry production to fungal colonization.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The substantial increase in fungal diseases, the limited availability of antifungal drugs, and rising resistance to existing treatments highlight the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs. Natural products, known for their diverse bioactivities and unique structures, remain critical sources for antifungal drug discovery. These multifaceted mechanisms highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents. The compound's multifaceted mechanism of action—targeting structural integrity while triggering cellular damage pathways—positions soil-derived natural products as sources for addressing the growing problem of antifungal resistance.  The identification of this compound from a soil microorganism reflects a deeper material entanglement: the same soil ecosystems that harbour fungal pathogens also contain bacterial producers of antifungal metabolites, yet the extraction and development of such compounds depends on industrial cultivation and chemical isolation processes that abstract these organisms from their ecological context. The compound's capacity to simultaneously damage cell walls, disrupt membrane function, and generate oxidative stress reveals how fungal vulnerability can be engineered into a therapeutic asset, though the paper does not address whether widespread deployment of such a compound might select for resistant strains or alter the microbial assemblages from which it originates.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Chemical fungicides act by targeting specific proteins or pathways, known as modes of action (MoAs). In this study, we established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. Target genes corresponding to major fungicide classes were deleted by homologous recombination, and the resulting mutants exhibited altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides compared with the wild-type strain. Several of these compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, underscoring their potential as novel scaffolds for future development.
