summary: This paper describes a genetic screening platform designed to identify antifungal compounds effective against Fusarium graminearum, a fungal pathogen of grain crops. The researchers deleted genes encoding known fungicide targets in the pathogen using homologous recombination, creating mutant strains with altered sensitivity profiles to existing fungicides. These mutants served as a diagnostic tool: screening a library of 2,704 small molecules against both wild-type and mutant strains revealed compounds that affected fungal growth through specific pathways. The study identified 8 compounds with activity linked to the osmotic signal transduction pathway—the cellular mechanism that allows fungi to sense and respond to water stress—several of which showed antifungal properties not previously documented. The platform detects active compounds by measuring changes in optical density at 600 nanometers, a standard measure of cell density and growth.  The dual logic of this approach—using genetic vulnerability to map chemical action—exposes a material tension in fungicide development. The same genetic deletions that make mutants sensitive to novel compounds also reveal why resistance emerges: fungi can survive by altering or abandoning specific pathways, a capacity that fungicides themselves select for under repeated application. The 8 newly identified compounds targeting osmotic signalling represent not a solution to resistance but a temporary advantage in an ongoing arms race shaped by agricultural intensification and monoculture. What this paper documents is not the discovery of a durable antifungal but rather the systematic production of knowledge about fungal vulnerability—knowledge that, once deployed in fields, will itself accelerate the evolution of tolerance in populations already stressed by the chemical and economic pressures of industrial grain production.

title: Occurrence of mycotoxins in fish feed and its consequences for aquaculture with special regard to the role of insect products
excerpt: Infection of plants with molds and inadequate storage conditions of plant materials contribute to contamination of crops like cereals, corn and soybeans with mycotoxins. Plant-derived ingredients serve as major protein sources in aquaculture feeds; however, the increasing use of insects as alternative nutrient sources introduces additional potential pathways for mycotoxin contamination. Strong evidence shows that exposure of fish to mycotoxins can negatively affect their health, leading to reduced growth, impaired immune response and reproductive disorders. However, knowledge of the effects of mycotoxins on farmed insects is still limited. Little is known about the insect metabolism of mycotoxins and their transfer to animal feed, which constitutes a weakness of safety assessments of insects as feed components. This review provides comprehensive information about the consequences of mycotoxin contamination of feed materials and feeds used in aquaculture. To facilitate understanding of the problem and its scale, the mycotoxin levels in plant materials and finished feeds used in aquaculture were compiled and analyzed together with the contamination levels of fish-derived food. Moreover, the available data on the effects of fish exposure to the selected mycotoxins are summarized, highlighting the complexity of the biological activity of these compounds. Finally, recent challenges to the safety of using insects as a protein source in fish nutrition are discussed. The information provided herein is important for assessing the health and economic risks of the growing use of modern feed ingredients in the sustainable aquaculture.
summary: Mold toxins produced during plant infection and poor storage contaminate cereals, corn, and soybeans destined for aquaculture feed. Plant-based ingredients remain the primary protein source in fish farming, but the shift toward farmed insects as alternative protein introduces new contamination pathways. This paper documents that fish exposed to mold toxins show reduced growth, weakened immune function, and reproductive failure. However, the metabolism of mold toxins in farmed insects remains poorly understood, and data on how insects process and transfer these toxins to feed are sparse—a critical gap in evaluating insect-based feed safety. This review compiles measured mold toxin levels across plant materials, finished aquaculture feeds, and fish-derived food sources, summarizes documented effects of specific mold toxins on fish health, and identifies unresolved safety questions around insects as a protein ingredient.  The expansion of insect farming as a sustainable feed source reveals a material entanglement: the same shift toward "modern" ingredients designed to reduce pressure on wild fish stocks and plant agriculture simultaneously introduces a biological pathway—insect metabolism—that remains largely opaque to safety assessment. Mold toxins move through feed chains in ways that depend on the specific organism processing them; what an insect does with a toxin differs from what a plant does, yet this difference is unmeasured and unaccounted for in current safety frameworks. The economic logic driving aquaculture intensification toward novel feed ingredients thus outpaces the knowledge required to identify where toxin accumulation occurs.

title: Basidiomycete-specific chitin synthase genes have clade-specific roles in cell wall formation and hyphal development in Pleurotus ostreatus
excerpt: Chitin, an essential structural component of most fungal cell walls, is produced by transmembrane proteins called chitin synthases (CHSs). Our previous study identified novel basidiomycete-specific chss (chsb) clades (BI–BIII) and suggested functional differences between the chsb genes of clade BII and BIII. This study, together with our previous work, presents the first comprehensive functional analysis and identification of clade-specific roles of chsb genes in vegetative hyphae of the white-rot fungus Pleurotus ostreatus. Using homologous recombination, we disrupted chsb1 (clade BI) and simultaneously disrupted chsb2 and chsb3 (clade BII) to investigate their roles in vegetative growth, cell wall biosynthesis and stress response. Deletion of chsb1 led to reduced colony growth, impaired aerial hyphae formation, thinner cell walls and significant cell wall remodelling. Using targeted gene deletion, the researchers disrupted chsb1 (clade BI) alone and chsb2 with chsb3 together (clade BII), then observed the consequences for hyphal growth, cell wall structure, and stress tolerance. Deletion of chsb1 produced measurable defects: reduced colony expansion, loss of upright filament formation, thinner protective cell walls, and widespread reorganization of wall composition. Disruption of chsb2 or chsb3 individually caused only minor effects, but deleting both genes simultaneously triggered severe impairment—complete absence of upright filaments, abnormal cell division patterns, and substantial growth failure. Both deletion strains accumulated higher absolute amounts of chitin despite their structural and developmental problems.  The findings reveal how a single structural polymer—chitin—can be simultaneously overproduced and functionally compromised depending on which enzyme variants are absent. In Pleurotus, the loss of specific chitin synthase genes triggers compensatory chitin accumulation that fails to restore normal cell wall architecture or growth capacity, suggesting that quantity of material and quality of assembly are decoupled processes. This material entanglement—where a fungus produces more of a critical polymer yet becomes more fragile and developmentally arrested—mirrors broader patterns in the Patchy Anthropocene where organisms and their products become simultaneously more abundant and less functional under stress, revealing how metabolic responses to disruption can paradoxically intensify vulnerability rather than resolve it.

title: Depletion of the Candida albicans TLO gene family reveals a requirement for alpha TLO genes for wild-type virulence
excerpt: Candida albicans uniquely possesses an expanded family of genes (the TLO gene family) that encodes 10–15 paralogues of the Med2 component of the transcriptional regulator Mediator. Previous studies have shown that TLO null mutants are unable to form hyphae and are hypersensitive to environmental stress. However, the reason for the TLO gene expansion remains unclear, and the current study aimed to determine if reduction in the TLO family copy number affected virulence. In order to investigate this, we used CRISPR-Cas9 mutagenesis to generate two TLO-depleted mutants: one mutant retaining only TLOβ2 (CaTLO2) and the second mutant containing only TLOγ5 (CaTLO5). Both TLO-depleted mutants exhibited increased filamentous growth, increased susceptibility to specific stresses and reduced virulence in a murine model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC). In vitro, the CaTLO5 mutant also exhibited impaired hyphal escape from macrophages and reduced hyphal invasion of oral keratinocytes. summary: Candida albicans possesses an unusually large family of TLO genes—10 to 15 copies—that produce variants of the Med2 protein, a component of the transcriptional regulator Mediator. Previous work showed that complete loss of all TLO genes prevents the organism from forming hyphae (elongated filamentous structures) and increases sensitivity to environmental stress, but the evolutionary advantage of maintaining multiple copies remained unexplained. This study used genetic editing to create two mutants: one retaining only the TLOβ2 gene variant and another retaining only the TLOγ5 variant. Both depleted mutants showed increased filamentous growth in culture, heightened vulnerability to specific stresses, and reduced ability to cause infection in mice with oropharyngeal candidiasis (a fungal infection of the mouth and throat). In cell-based assays, the TLOγ5 mutant specifically showed impaired capacity to escape from immune cells called macrophages and reduced ability to invade oral skin cells. The researchers then tested whether adding back the TLOα1 gene variant—previously shown to restore normal growth in completely TLO-depleted strains—could restore disease-causing ability, though the abstract does not report the outcome of this complementation experiment.  The TLO gene expansion in Candida albicans appears to encode functional redundancy tied directly to pathogenic capacity: the same genetic duplication that allows the organism to maintain disease-causing ability under stress also constrains its ability to survive immune pressure and invade host tissues when copy number drops. The tension emerges not between pathogen and resource, but between genetic robustness and clinical vulnerability—a pattern shaped by the selective pressures of human mucosal colonization and the specific immunological barriers of oral epithelium.

title: Lack of a putative intrinsically disordered protein anchored to the sporangiospore cell wall causes fragile sporangium formation in Actinoplanes missouriensis

Each sporangium, surrounded by an outer envelope, contains a few hundred spores encapsulated by the sporangium matrix. summary: The filamentous bacterium Actinoplanes missouriensis produces terminal sporangia—spherical structures containing hundreds of spores held together by a matrix and outer envelope. This paper identifies a protein called SspA, displayed on the spore surface and anchored to the cell wall through a sortase-dependent mechanism, as essential for sporangium structural integrity. The mature form of SspA is predicted to be an intrinsically disordered protein, a type lacking fixed three-dimensional shape. When the gene encoding SspA was deleted, sporangia still formed but became mechanically fragile, collapsing immediately when exposed to aqueous solutions and releasing spores prematurely. Transmission electron microscopy showed that sporangia lacking SspA failed to mature properly: the electron-dense matrix material that normally surrounds individual spores in the peripheral region was absent, and the outer envelope of some sporangia was visibly damaged. Peptide-tagged versions of SspA produced in the mutant strain were detected on zoospore surfaces using the HiBiT detection system.  The structural failure of sporangia without SspA reveals a material dependency embedded in the life cycle of this bacterium. A single protein—disordered in structure yet precisely positioned on the spore surface—appears to mediate the cohesion between individual spores and the matrix that contains them, a function that becomes visible only through its absence. This arrangement exemplifies how microbial survival strategies depend on specific material assemblages: the sporangium envelope, matrix, and surface proteins form an integrated system where weakness in one component cascades into collective fragility, suggesting that the robustness of these bacterial structures emerges not from rigid architectural design but from distributed material interactions that can fail catastrophically when disrupted.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. While Aspergillus fumigatus remains the predominant species causing human infections, recent studies highlight the growing clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, which often exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. In this study, we analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. A total of 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections were identified, with non- fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto (22.9%), A. sydowii (8.7%), A. calidoustus (7.1%), A. nidulans (6.6%), A. tanneri (6.1%), and A. terreus (5.6%). Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In contrast, PCR sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. summary: This study analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients at the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022, identifying 38 distinct Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections. Non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounted for 77.1% of all isolates, with Aspergillus fumigatus sensu stricto representing only 22.9% of recovered organisms. Species identification success varied substantially by method: matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry achieved identification in 43% of isolates, while polymerase chain reaction sequencing of the internal transcribed spacer region succeeded in over 88% of cases, the β-tubulin gene in 81%, and the calmodulin gene in 68%. The most common underlying conditions among infected patients were bronchiectasis (35%), chronic granulomatous disease (22%), and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (17%), with mortality of 7.5% overall but concentrated among patients with chronic granulomatous disease and those with RAG1 deficiency. Antifungal susceptibility testing revealed that olorofim demonstrated the lowest minimum inhibitory concentrations across species, while triazoles and amphotericin B showed variable activity, particularly reduced effectiveness against Aspergillus tanneri, Aspergillus calidoustus, and Aspergillus sydowii.  Within damaged or immunologically compromised lung tissue—bronchiectatic airways, granulomatous lesions, sites of mycobacterial coinfection—the Aspergillus species composition shifts dramatically from the canonical fumigatus toward a diverse assemblage of lesser-known organisms that resist standard pharmaceutical interventions. This paper documents not merely a clinical inconvenience but a material reorganization of fungal dominance within specific human ecologies: the same immune-weakened bodies that enable fumigatus infection simultaneously select for and concentrate species whose reduced drug susceptibility transforms them into both a therapeutic problem and, potentially, a marker of deeper structural vulnerabilities in how antifungal treatment regimens are designed and deployed.

title: Phosphorene based nano-sensors for mycotoxins in food products: a review
excerpt: Mycotoxins are toxic fungal metabolites that pose serious challenges to worldwide food safety. It necessitates the rapid and sensitive methods for real-time detection of these compounds in food products. Conventional detection approaches are accurate, but their complexity, high cost and time consumption often create obstacles. The use of nanosensors, particularly those based on 2D-nanomaterials like phosphorene, are novel means for quick, sensitive, and low-cost detection of mycotoxins. Its tunable bandgap, high surface-to-volume ratio, and high electron mobility enables fast, sensitive, and low-cost detection of mycotoxins in real-food samples. Advances in synthesis and functionalization of phosphorene have improved its stability and integration into electrochemical, optical and field-effect transistor based sensors. Such phosphorene-based nanosensors exhibited exceptional low detection limits with improved selectivity for real-time monitoring of complex food products. Overall, phosphorene derived nanosensors have been established to be an innovative technology for on-site monitoring of mycotoxin contamination, facilitating overcome the challenges in food quality control.
summary: This paper surveys phosphorene-based nanosensors as detection tools for mycotoxins in food products. The source identifies mycotoxins—toxic compounds produced by fungi—as a persistent food safety problem requiring rapid, sensitive detection methods. Conventional detection approaches, while accurate, are complex, expensive, and time-consuming. This study examines phosphorene, a two-dimensional nanomaterial with a tunable bandgap, high surface-to-volume ratio, and high electron mobility, as the basis for faster and cheaper detection systems. Recent advances in phosphorene synthesis and chemical modification have improved its stability and enabled integration into electrochemical sensors, optical sensors, and field-effect transistor sensors. This paper reports that phosphorene-based nanosensors achieve exceptionally low detection limits with improved selectivity for monitoring mycotoxins in real food samples, positioning the technology as viable for on-site contamination monitoring.  The dual character of this technological development reflects broader patterns in food safety infrastructure under resource constraint. Phosphorene nanosensors promise to democratize mycotoxin detection—moving it from expensive laboratory facilities to on-site, low-cost monitoring—yet this same shift relocates detection capacity away from centralized oversight toward distributed, decentralized points in food supply chains. The material properties that make phosphorene effective (its sensitivity, its capacity to integrate with multiple sensor types) are the same properties that render it dependent on continued synthesis, functionalization, and maintenance; the promise of accessible detection thus entangles food producers and retailers in new technical dependencies and supply relationships.

title: Occurrence of toxigenic fungi and mycotoxins in pig feeds: potential implications for workers’ exposure

summary: This study examined nine pig feed samples from intensive farms in Southern Italy to determine whether feeds serve as a source of occupational exposure to toxigenic fungi and their toxic metabolites. Researchers isolated 35 mold colonies total, with *Aspergillus flavus* comprising 46 percent of isolates, followed by *Aspergillus niger* and *Aspergillus candidus* at 11.43 percent each. Of the 16 *Aspergillus flavus* strains recovered, half carried all five genes required for aflatoxin production, yet only four strains demonstrated actual aflatoxin-producing capacity when tested by high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry, with aflatoxin B1 levels ranging from 0.52 to 1030 micrograms per liter. Ochratoxin A appeared in all nine feed samples at a mean concentration of 33.6 micrograms per kilogram, while Fumonisin B1 was detected in 97 percent of samples at 247.1 micrograms per kilogram; only one sample contained Aflatoxin B1 at 5.84 micrograms per kilogram, a substance classified as carcinogenic to humans.  The presence of these toxigenic fungi and their metabolites in feed materials reveals a material pathway through which occupational hazard enters the farm workplace. The genetic capacity for toxin production does not guarantee actual toxin release—a gap illustrated by the discrepancy between strains carrying biosynthetic genes and those demonstrating measurable aflatoxin output—yet the feeds themselves remain contaminated with multiple mycotoxins regardless of their origin, creating a tangible exposure risk for workers handling these materials daily. Feed contamination thus operates simultaneously as an indicator of agricultural vulnerability to fungal colonization and as a mechanism through which workers become exposed to carcinogenic substances embedded in the routine materials of intensive animal production.

title: Aflatoxin surveillance in Punjab’s dairy sector: feed and milk contamination

summary: This panel-type longitudinal study tracked aflatoxin contamination in milk and feed across Punjab, Pakistan over multiple months, collecting 300 milk samples and 300 feed samples monthly from 36 districts stratified into five geographic clusters (north, south, east, west, and central). Samples were analysed using competitive enzyme immunoassay kits, with data from laboratory analyses and face-to-face interviews examined using statistical software. The study found significant correlations between education levels and awareness of aflatoxin contamination, with higher education associated with reduced contamination levels. Aflatoxin levels were highest in the central region, a pattern linked to farmers' reliance on self-stored grains. Training on aflatoxin management showed significant impact, though the abstract does not specify the outcome measures.  Within Punjab's dairy sector, contamination emerges not as a uniform biological threat but as a stratified exposure shaped by material storage practices and educational access. The concentration of aflatoxins in the central region—tied to on-farm grain storage—reveals how economic constraints and agricultural infrastructure determine which populations encounter higher mycotoxin loads in their feed and milk. Education functions here as both a marker of awareness and a proxy for economic position: farmers with greater schooling possess resources to adopt safer storage methods and market engagement, while those dependent on self-stored grains face both the biological hazard and the structural conditions that produce it. The efficacy of training interventions suggests that contamination is not inevitable but rather contingent on knowledge and material capacity—a pattern that implicates broader patterns of rural inequality in how mycotoxin exposure is distributed across the region.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.
summary: Gliotoxin, a toxic compound produced by certain fungi, was detected only in *Aspergillus fumigatus* isolates among 140 clinical samples from two hospitals analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography and liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry. No other fungal species tested produced gliotoxin under any of the culture conditions examined. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed that related fungal species produce distinct toxic metabolites instead: *Aspergillus flavus* produces aspirochlorine derivatives, while *Aspergillus terreus* produces aranotin-related compounds. This paper clarifies that gliotoxin production is restricted to *A. fumigatus* among the clinical isolates examined, while other *Aspergillus* species have evolved separate metabolic pathways for producing structurally related toxins.  The distribution of these species-specific toxins across clinical *Aspergillus* isolates reflects a material reality of hospital environments: the same genus of fungus circulating through medical settings produces different chemical weapons depending on which species colonizes a patient's lungs or wounds. Gliotoxin's restriction to *A. fumigatus* does not make the other species less clinically relevant—it redirects attention to their own toxic metabolites as equally important drivers of infection and tissue damage. What emerges is not a simple hierarchy of pathogenic threat but a fragmented landscape of fungal toxicity, where clinical risk depends on which particular species establishes itself in a given body, under given conditions of immune suppression, antibiotic exposure, or architectural vulnerability.

title: An integrated multiscale computational study of nephrotoxicity mechanism of citrinin and its metabolites (CIMs)：density functional theory, network toxicology, and molecular dynamics simulation
excerpt: Citrinin is a common mycotoxin found in food and poses risks to both human and animal health. While extensive research has been conducted on the nephrotoxicity of citrinin itself, the nephrotoxicity of its metabolites remains unclear. Therefore, this study investigated the nephrotoxic mechanism of citrinin and its metabolites (CIMs) using density functional theory, network toxicology, and computer simulations. Our findings revealed that CIMs also have potential toxicity, such as nephrotoxicity. Density functional theory explained the structural basis of the toxicity of CIMs. A total of 255 targets related to nephrotoxicity induced by CIMs were predicted by network toxicology. Notably, the enrichment results indicated the importance of multiple forms of programmed cell death in CIMs-induced nephrotoxicity. In addition, four key targets (TP53, MAPK1, MAPK3, and HSP90AA1) were identified, with molecular dynamics simulations validating stable binding between the four targets and CIMs. Van der Waals forces were the main driving force for stabilizing complexes formed between CIMs and the four targets through the binding free energy and independent gradient model analysis. summary: Citrinin is a mould toxin commonly present in food that damages kidney tissue in humans and animals. This paper used three computational approaches—quantum chemistry calculations, network analysis of biological targets, and molecular simulations—to understand how citrinin and its breakdown products harm kidney cells. The study identified 255 biological targets involved in kidney damage caused by these compounds, with particular emphasis on multiple pathways of programmed cell death. Four key proteins (TP53, MAPK1, MAPK3, and HSP90AA1) were found to bind stably with citrinin and its metabolites; molecular dynamics simulations showed that weak intermolecular forces (van der Waals forces) were the primary mechanism holding these protein-toxin complexes together.  The paper documents a dual material condition: the same mould metabolites that circulate through food systems as unregulated contaminants are simultaneously recognized as biochemically active agents capable of triggering cell death pathways in kidney tissue. The identification of specific protein targets and binding mechanisms reveals how toxicity operates not as a simple property of the compound itself, but as a relational outcome—dependent on which proteins the metabolite encounters within the body and under what conditions. This computational mapping of toxin-protein interactions effectively renders visible the material entanglement between food contamination, mould metabolism, and human cellular vulnerability, while the focus on metabolites (rather than the parent toxin alone) suggests that the kidney-damaging threat persists and transforms through biological processing rather than being neutralized.

title: Aflatoxin B1 interferes with lncRNA-mRNA network to inhibit proliferation of bovine endometrial epithelial cells
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a common feed contaminant, causes substantial economic losses in animal husbandry and threatens reproductive health. This study investigated the toxic mechanisms of AFB1 on bovine endometrial epithelial cells using in vitro experiments. Treatment with 5 μg/mL AFB1 for 24 h significantly inhibited cell proliferation and induced apoptosis, indicated by a reduced EdU-positive rate and increased Bax/Bcl-2 ratio and Caspase-3 expression. Transcriptome sequencing identified 810 differentially expressed mRNAs and 88 upregulated lncRNAs, which were primarily enriched in calcium signaling, oxytocin, and GnRH pathways. Experimental validation confirmed that AFB1 elevated intracellular Ca2⁺ levels, dysregulated calcium-related protein expression, and disrupted mitochondrial membrane potential. Further analysis suggested that lncRNAs such as MSTRG.32635 may perturb cellular homeostasis by modulating calcium signaling–associated genes. These findings elucidate a novel mechanism wherein AFB1 impairs endometrial cell function via an lncRNA–mRNA network that interferes with calcium signaling, offering potential targets for the prevention and treatment of AFB1-induced reproduct
summary: This paper documents how aflatoxin B1, a mycotoxin commonly found in animal feed, disrupts the reproductive tissue of cattle at the molecular level. Exposure to 5 micrograms per milliliter of aflatoxin B1 for 24 hours halted cell division in bovine endometrial epithelial cells and triggered programmed cell death, measured through reduced incorporation of a DNA synthesis marker and increased markers of cell death (elevated Bax/Bcl-2 ratio and Caspase-3 expression). Sequencing of cellular RNA revealed 810 genes with altered expression levels and 88 long non-coding RNA molecules that showed increased activity, with these molecules concentrated in pathways governing calcium movement, oxytocin signaling, and reproductive hormone release. The study confirmed that aflatoxin B1 raised calcium levels inside cells, disrupted proteins that manage calcium, and damaged the energy-producing structures within cells. Analysis indicated that specific long non-coding RNA molecules, including one designated MSTRG.32635, may destabilize cellular balance by interfering with genes involved in calcium regulation.  The findings reveal how a feed contaminant generates reproductive harm not through direct toxicity alone but through a layered molecular network—one that couples microbial metabolite, genetic regulation, and cellular signaling in ways that render reproductive tissue vulnerable. The same feed systems that concentrate aflatoxin-producing fungi as an economic byproduct of grain storage and transport simultaneously expose livestock to disrupted calcium signaling and reproductive failure, embedding occupational and animal health risks within the material infrastructure of intensive animal agriculture.

title: Human biomonitoring of mycotoxins: key challenges and future directions
excerpt:
Mycotoxins pose a major health risk for humans in many parts of the world. For exposure assessment human biomonitoring (HBM) based on the analysis of serum, plasma, whole blood, urine or breast milk samples is a powerful approach which has been extensively used. However, there are several major challenges and pitfalls to be considered to achieve reliable and standardized data which can be used for risk assessment. These challenges include sampling (spot urine, 24 h urine, plasma, serum etc.) and analytical issues (missing reference standards, matrix effects, protein adducts, recovery, limit of detection, stability during storage, etc.). Further critical aspects needed for biomarker interpretation and human health risk evaluation are a lack of data for several mycotoxins such as (a) health-based guidance values (b) long-term biomarkers, (c) reliable food intake data (d) toxicokinetic parameters in humans, for example clearance and transfer rates to urine or milk and (e) HBM guidance values. In this review, these issues will be discussed based on recent HBM studies and recommendations for future studies as well as research needs will be derived.

summary: This paper identifies critical gaps in the standardization and interpretation of human biomonitoring data for mycotoxins—fungal poisons that accumulate in food systems and enter human bodies through consumption. The study documents major technical obstacles: sampling inconsistencies (whether urine is collected as a single spot sample or over 24 hours; whether blood plasma or serum is used), analytical problems (absence of reference standards for comparison, interference from sample matrix components, difficulty measuring protein-bound mycotoxin forms, variable recovery rates, detection limits too high to catch low exposures, and degradation during storage), and fundamental knowledge gaps about how mycotoxins move through human bodies and how much exposure causes harm. This paper reviews recent biomonitoring studies and outlines what future research must address to produce reliable exposure data suitable for health risk assessment.  The tension documented here reflects a deeper entanglement: mycotoxins are simultaneously ubiquitous food contaminants and poorly characterized human exposures. The machinery for detecting them in human tissues exists but remains fragmented across incompatible methods and unstandardized protocols—a fragmentation that mirrors the patchy geography of mycotoxin contamination itself, where exposure varies sharply by food supply, storage conditions, and access to tested products. Without harmonized biomonitoring frameworks and basic toxicokinetic data, the capacity to document and quantify human harm remains unequally distributed, leaving populations dependent on contaminated food systems unable to establish baseline exposure or track whether interventions work.

title: Probiotics as eco-friendlybio-preservatives: In vivo mechanisms of mycotoxin inhibition and emerging applications for food safety and human health
excerpt: Probiotics present a promising and sustainable solution for mitigating the harmful effects of mycotoxins in food thereby resolving a critical concern for global food safety. This review highlights probiotics’ role as eco-friendly bio-preservatives that inhibit both the production and effects of mycotoxins in food systems. It explores the in vivo and in vivo mechanisms through which probiotics neutralize mycotoxins, prevent their carcinogenic effects and improve food safety. These findings indicate the potential of probiotics dual function in preventing mycotoxin contamination at the food level and mitigating their harmful impacts upon ingestion. The review incorporates experimental case studies and innovations in probiotic research, emphasizing their potential as safe and effective alternatives to synthetic chemical detoxifiers. Despite significant progress in grasping the role of probiotics, hurdles remain such as strain specificity, limited clinical data and environmental factors affecting probiotic efficacy. summary: This review examines probiotics as biological preservatives that work against mycotoxins—toxic compounds produced by moulds—in food systems. The paper describes two mechanisms of action: probiotics can inhibit mycotoxin production directly and can also neutralize mycotoxins after they form, thereby preventing their carcinogenic effects when contaminated food is consumed. The review synthesizes experimental case studies demonstrating probiotics' capacity to function both as preventive agents at the food production stage and as mitigating agents within the human body after ingestion. The authors position probiotics as alternatives to synthetic chemical detoxifiers, though they acknowledge significant limitations: strain-specific effectiveness varies widely, clinical evidence in human populations remains sparse, and environmental conditions substantially affect whether probiotics perform as intended.  Within the material entanglements of industrial food production, probiotics emerge as both a solution and a symptom of deeper dependencies. These living organisms are enlisted to manage contamination caused by other living organisms—moulds that thrive in the same conditions of storage, transport, and economic pressure that make food systems vulnerable. The dual function attributed to probiotics here—preventing mould-derived toxins while also remediating their effects in human bodies—reveals how biological management strategies can obscure rather than resolve the structural conditions that enable mycotoxin contamination in the first place. What appears as an eco-friendly alternative to chemical intervention is simultaneously a technology that allows food systems organized around speed, storage, and profit to persist without fundamental restructuring.

title: Occurrence and Quantification of Fusarium Mycotoxins in Wheat Grains from Uruguay
source: acs: ACS Food Science & Technology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Fusarium head blight (FHB) is a major limitation for wheat production in Uruguay. This study aimed to optimize a method for the determination of mycotoxins produced by Fusarium in wheat grains. A validated HPLC-MS/MS method was used to analyze zearalenone (ZEA) and type B trichothecenes─deoxynivalenol (DON), 3-acetyldeoxynivalenol (3ADON), 15-acetyldeoxynivalenol (15ADON), and nivalenol (NIV)─in 71 commercial samples from the 2018 season across various cultivars and locations. Mycotoxins were detected in 47 samples, with DON being the most prevalent (46/47), ranging from 102 to 10,507 μg/kg. NIV was quantified in 8 samples (37–66 μg/kg), ZEA in 6 (104–5193 μg/kg), and 3ADON in one sample (67 μg/kg); 15ADON was not detected. FHB-susceptible cultivars showed more positive samples and higher DON and ZEA levels, while moderately resistant cultivars generally had lower concentrations. However, no significant differences in DON content were observed among cultivars.
summary: Fusarium head blight is a significant constraint on wheat production in Uruguay. This paper used liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry to measure five mycotoxins—zearalenone, deoxynivalenol, 3-acetyldeoxynivalenol, 15-acetyldeoxynivalenol, and nivalenol—in 71 commercial wheat samples collected from the 2018 harvest across multiple cultivars and regions. Mycotoxins were detected in 47 samples, with deoxynivalenol present in 46 of these, ranging from 102 to 10,507 micrograms per kilogram. Nivalenol appeared in 8 samples at levels between 37 and 66 micrograms per kilogram, zearalenone in 6 samples between 104 and 5,193 micrograms per kilogram, and 3-acetyldeoxynivalenol in one sample at 67 micrograms per kilogram; 15-acetyldeoxynivalenol was not detected. Cultivars bred for susceptibility to head blight showed higher rates of contamination and elevated concentrations of deoxynivalenol and zearalenone, though cultivars with moderate resistance did not consistently show lower deoxynivalenol levels across all samples tested.  The contamination patterns documented in this paper reveal how crop genetics and fungal toxin accumulation are entangled within commercial wheat supply chains. The persistent presence of deoxynivalenol across nearly all contaminated samples, alongside the variable appearance of secondary toxins, suggests that Fusarium populations in Uruguayan wheat fields are metabolically flexible—capable of producing multiple toxic compounds under different field conditions, yet reliably producing one dominant toxin regardless of cultivar choice. This pattern reflects not merely a biological fact but a material condition of contemporary grain production: the toxins that mark certain wheat batches as unmarketable in regulated economies can simultaneously serve as indicators of which cultivars and growing regions require intervention, creating new sites where agricultural management, trade standards, and fungal metabolism converge.

title: Dynamics of Kojic Acid and Other Compositions during Solid-State Fermentation of Two White Grape Pomaces by Aspergillus oryzae and tamarii
source: acs: ACS Food Science & Technology: Table of Contents
excerpt: This study aimed to optimize a solid-state fermentation approach to produce valuable substances from two grape pomace (GP) varieties fermented with two Aspergillus strains (A. oryzae and A. tamarii) with aqueous extract samples collected over 6 days. The aqueous extracts were characterized by °Brix, pH, titratable acidity, total phenolics, 4 individual sugars, 5 organic acids, and 4 phenolics. The results showed °Brix, pH, and titratable acidity changed monotonically with fermentation, corresponding to changes in individual sugars and organic acids. Fermentation nearly depleted fructose (98–99%), glucose (>99%), and tartaric acid (62–99%), lowering °Brix and titratable acidity while raising pH. Fermentation also significantly increased gallic acid (124–159%) and produced kojic acid (0.041 g/g pomace dry mass). Phenolic extraction was maximized with 1–3 days of fermentations. The PCA biplot showed that fermentation duration and GP variety were the primary drivers of variation in chemical composition, while strain type had minimal impact. The increased phenolic extraction and novel production of kojic acid demonstrated GP’s potential as a source of valuable microbial metabolites.
summary: Solid-state fermentation of white grape pomace using two Aspergillus strains (A. oryzae and A. tamarii) over six days produced measurable changes in chemical composition. The fermentation process nearly depleted simple sugars—fructose (98–99%) and glucose (>99%)—and tartaric acid (62–99%), while substantially increasing gallic acid (124–159%) and generating kojic acid at 0.041 grams per gram of pomace dry mass. Fermentation duration and pomace variety were the primary drivers of chemical change, whereas the choice between the two Aspergillus strains had minimal effect. Phenolic extraction peaked between days one and three of fermentation.  Within the material entanglement of wine production and fungal metabolism, this paper documents how a byproduct of industrial viticulture—grape pomace—becomes a site where fungal growth simultaneously extracts existing phenolic compounds and generates novel metabolites like kojic acid. The same Aspergillus species that signal spoilage or contamination in other contexts here function as metabolic factories, converting agricultural waste into compounds with potential pharmaceutical or cosmetic value. This dual capacity reveals how the valuation of fungal activity depends entirely on location and intention: the same fermentation process that would constitute spoilage in a wine cellar becomes productive accumulation in a fermentation vessel, turning material exclusion into economic resource.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.
summary: This paper isolates eight new alkaloid compounds with a decahydrofluorene skeleton from a marine-derived strain of *Penicillium* fungus collected from the South China Sea. The researchers determined the three-dimensional structures of these compounds using spectroscopic methods, quantum chemical modelling of light absorption patterns, and X-ray crystallography. Nine of the isolated compounds demonstrated cell-damaging activity against human lung cancer cells and colorectal cancer cells, with half-maximal inhibitory concentrations ranging from 7.3 to 79.3 micromolar. Seven compounds also inhibited the growth of six pathogenic bacterial species, with minimum inhibitory concentrations between 1.6 and 13.0 micrograms per millilitre.  The compounds emerge from a marine fungus that has been deliberately sourced and cultured for bioactive secondary metabolites — a deliberate extraction of chemical production from a nonhuman organism. Yet the same alkaloids that arrest human cancer cell division and suppress bacterial pathogens represent a form of fungal metabolic capacity shaped by the organism's own ecological pressures and chemical defences. This paper documents how marine fungi, organisms often treated as sources of raw material for pharmaceutical development, simultaneously embody both therapeutic potential and the capacity for independent chemical synthesis driven by their own survival strategies in competitive marine environments.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Mold identification in clinical diagnostics is traditionally labor-intensive and is dependent on expert interpretation. We analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (with A. flavus and A. fumigatus ), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. Daily images were captured from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days using a standardized smartphone setup, generating over 4,000 images. We trained three variations of Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and benchmarked the best-performing model (VGG16 with dual classification heads) against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments at various time points. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean (SD) AUROC of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). Regarding the evaluations over time, early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5% across all species) but improved significantly on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8% across all species). summary: This paper presents MoldVision, a deep-learning system trained to identify mold species from smartphone photographs of laboratory cultures. The study analyzed 161 clinical isolates from four mold genera—Penicillium, Aspergillus (including A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium, and Cladosporium—capturing over 4,000 images from culture plate tops and bottoms across five days using standardized smartphone equipment. A convolutional neural network model (Visual Geometry Group 16 with dual classification heads) achieved an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species, with notably stronger performance on Cladosporium identification (99.9% ± 0.1%). The system struggled with early-stage classification on days 1–2 (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5%) but performed substantially better on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8%), consistently outperforming human expert assessments, particularly in detecting subtle morphological features in mature cultures.  The findings reveal a material entanglement between diagnostic labor and technological substitution. The same mold cultures that traditionally demanded scarce expert time and specialized knowledge—resources unevenly distributed across laboratories, particularly in resource-limited settings—now become data sources for automated classification. Yet this automation does not simply replace human expertise; it redistributes it. The system's dependence on standardized smartphone imaging, five-day culture growth periods, and computational infrastructure creates new forms of technical gatekeeping even as it promises accessibility. What emerges is not the elimination of expert labor but its transformation into a different kind of scarcity: the capacity to generate, curate, and validate training datasets becomes the new bottleneck, concentrating diagnostic power in institutions with resources to build and maintain machine-learning systems.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Nitric oxide (NO) is an important biological signaling molecule. S -nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a master regulator of NO signaling, regulates various biological processes. However, little is known about the role of GSNOR in Aspergillus flavus . Here, we identified a gene encoding GSNOR in this aflatoxigenic fungus and demonstrated that GSNOR shows activity during the critical life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. We found that GSNOR plays a crucial role in NO homeostasis, as GSNOR deletion resulted in significantly elevated NO levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous NO stress. GSNOR also participated in multiple biological processes in A. flavus ; for that, GSNOR deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis and sclerotial development, attenuated virulence on kernels, and notably decreased aflatoxin production. Furthermore, we demonstrated that GSNOR is important for reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance, as its deletion significantly elevated mycelial ROS levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. IMPORTANCE Aspergillus flavus is a notorious saprophytic filamentous fungus, with its production of carcinogenic aflatoxins posing serious threats to food safety and human health. Aflatoxin contamination prevention and control have long been a global challenge. In previous studies, we observed that nitric oxide (NO) significantly inhibits the aflatoxin production by A. flavus . This study further investigated the role of the key regulatory enzyme S -nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) in the NO signaling pathway. Our findings indicate that GSNOR is crucial for maintaining both NO homeostasis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance and plays an essential role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis. summary: Nitric oxide homeostasis in Aspergillus flavus is regulated by the enzyme S-nitrosoglutathione reductase, which this paper identifies as essential for controlling nitrogen oxide signaling in the fungus. When S-nitrosoglutathione reductase was deleted, nitric oxide accumulated to elevated levels and the fungus became hypersensitive to external nitric oxide stress. The deletion also disrupted the fungus's ability to manage reactive oxygen species, causing accumulation of these damaging molecules and increased vulnerability to oxidative stress. Across multiple developmental stages—spore germination, hyphal growth, and spore formation—S-nitrosoglutathione reductase deletion impaired fungal development, reduced growth rate, weakened the ability to form protective sclerotial structures, and notably decreased production of aflatoxin, the carcinogenic compound that makes Aspergillus flavus a major food safety hazard. The fungus also showed reduced capacity to infect crop kernels when S-nitrosoglutathione reductase was absent.  The dual role of nitric oxide emerges here as both constraint and opportunity: the same signaling pathway that the fungus requires for normal development and toxin production is simultaneously a point of vulnerability that could be exploited for control. This paper suggests that blocking components of the nitric oxide signaling pathway—specifically S-nitrosoglutathione reductase—could suppress aflatoxin biosynthesis without necessarily killing the organism outright, positioning chemical interference with fungal signaling as a potential food safety intervention. Yet this approach also reveals a deeper entanglement: controlling a pathogenic fungus through its own regulatory machinery means targeting the same molecular systems that govern its basic survival and reproduction, raising questions about whether such interventions remain stable or whether selective pressure might generate fungal variants that circumvent this constraint.

title: Dietary melegueta seed powder modulates growth, hepatic function, and biomarkers to counteract aflatoxin B₁ toxicity in broilers

summary: Aframomum melegueta seed powder, a plant-derived supplement containing phytochemicals with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity, was tested for its ability to protect broiler chickens from aflatoxin B₁ toxicity. Over six weeks, 320 Cobb 500 chicks received one of four diets: a control diet, a diet containing 0.4 milligrams per kilogram of aflatoxin B₁ alone, or aflatoxin B₁ combined with either 0.5 or 1.0 grams per kilogram of AMSP. Aflatoxin B₁ exposure alone reduced final body weight from 2,743.23 grams to 2,315.82 grams, lowered protein intake, and increased feed conversion ratio from 1.47 to 1.70. The toxin also reduced packed cell volume (from 35.05% to 29.37%) and haemoglobin concentration (from 11.68 to 9.79 grams per decilitre), while elevating liver enzymes including ALT (from 16.77 to 24.04 international units per litre) and AST (from 57.59 to 70.62 international units per litre). AMSP supplementation at 1.0 grams per kilogram restored growth performance and blood markers to control levels, while 0.5 grams per kilogram achieved partial recovery.  Within feed systems dependent on grain storage, aflatoxin contamination and its remediation reveal overlapping vulnerabilities and dependencies. The same agricultural conditions that enable fungal toxin accumulation in stored feed—moisture, temperature, time—create the material context in which plant-based supplements become economically viable interventions. This paper documents not a simple solution but a calibration: the dose-related efficacy of AMSP suggests that protection against mycotoxin damage operates as a market-dependent variable, where the cost and availability of supplementation shape which animals receive which level of mitigation across different production systems.

title: Emerging toxins and emerging concerns: determination of selected mycotoxins in rabbit and rodent pet food using liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry
excerpt: Emerging mycotoxins are defined as fungal metabolites not yet regulated or routinely monitored—are gaining attention due to their potential health impacts and widespread occurrence in food and feed. These emerging mycotoxins are known to exert diverse in vitro toxic effects. Furthermore, they share relevant antimicrobial properties, which may affect intestinal microbiota and hence gut health, immunity and animal welfare, particularly in herbivorous species. Despite growing interest in small herbivorous pets such as rabbits and rodents, limited data are available on mycotoxin contamination in their commercial diets. This study aimed to develop and validate a reliable LC–MS/MS method for the simultaneous determination of selected emerging mycotoxins—such as beauvericin (BEAU), enniatins (ENN A, A1, B, B1), and alternariol (AOH)—in rabbit and rodent feed. A total of 200 feed samples (100 each for rabbit and rodent feed) were randomly collected from pet shops and markets in Bangkok, Thailand. Sample preparation was based on the QuEChERS approach, and detection was performed using liquid chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry with electrospray ionization in multiple reaction monitoring mode. Method validation was conducted according to SANTE/11,312/2021 guidelines, demonstrating acceptable performance in terms of selectivity, linearity, recovery, precision, and LOQ. The results revealed contamination with at least one emerging mycotoxin in 50% of rabbit feed and 39% of rodent feed samples, with BEAU being the most frequently detected compound. Co-contamination of BEAU and ENNs was found in 13.2% of rabbit feed and 8.2% of rodent feed samples, while AOH was not detected. These findings highlight the need for routine monitoring of emerging mycotoxins in pet food, especially for herbivorous small pets that may be rather vulnerable to microbiota-disrupting agents. summary: This study developed and validated a chemical detection method for emerging mycotoxins in small pet food, testing 200 commercial feed samples from Bangkok markets. The researchers used liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry to identify three classes of fungal toxins—beauvericin, enniatins (four variants), and alternariol—in rabbit and rodent diets. Half of rabbit feed samples and 39 percent of rodent feed samples contained at least one of these mycotoxins, with beauvericin appearing most frequently; 13.2 percent of rabbit feed and 8.2 percent of rodent feed showed simultaneous contamination with beauvericin and enniatins, while alternariol was absent from all samples. The method met validation standards for selectivity, linearity, recovery, and precision, offering a practical tool for quality monitoring.  These findings expose a material entanglement between pet food production and fungal metabolite accumulation in supply chains serving herbivorous animals with limited regulatory oversight. The selective vulnerability of rabbits and rodents—whose gut microbiota can be disrupted by these toxins—reveals how emerging mycotoxins operate simultaneously as unmonitored contaminants and as agents that reshape the internal ecology of captive herbivores, creating new dependencies on feed quality assurance systems that currently do not exist. The contamination pattern across Bangkok's pet food markets suggests that the absence of routine monitoring does not indicate the absence of exposure, but rather the absence of institutional capacity to detect what is materially present.

title: Optimization and validation of a targeted high-throughput UHPLC-MS/MS method for the analysis of multiple mycotoxins in chicken serum, egg yolk and white
excerpt: Mycotoxins, produced by fungi, contaminate animal feed and subsequently enter food products like eggs, posing significant health risks. This study aimed to optimize and validate a sensitive, cost-efficient, high-throughput UHPLC-MS/MS method for the qualitative analysis of 38 mycotoxins, and the quantification of 30, 29 and 29 regulated and emerging mycotoxins in chicken serum, egg yolk and egg white, respectively. Sample preparation involved liquid extraction with 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile, followed by protein and phospholipid removal using Oasis® Ostro™. This high-throughput method processed 96 samples within 4 h. Chromatographic separation was performed on an Acquity Premier BEH C18 column using 0.1% acetic acid in both water and methanol as mobile phases, with gradient elution. The MS/MS instrument employed electrospray ionization polarity switching and operated in multiple reaction monitoring mode. To enhance performance, ¹³C-labeled internal standards were utilized. summary: This paper describes the development of a high-throughput liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method to detect fungal toxins across chicken tissues and eggs. The study optimized analysis of 38 fungal toxins, with quantification of 30 in chicken serum, 29 in egg yolk, and 29 in egg white. Sample preparation used solvent extraction followed by removal of proteins and phospholipids; the method processed 96 samples in four hours. Chromatographic separation employed an Acquity Premier BEH C18 column with water and methanol as mobile phases under gradient conditions, while the mass spectrometer used electrospray ionization with polarity switching and monitored multiple reaction transitions. Validation followed European guidelines with detection thresholds set at 200 nanograms per millilitre for serum and 20 micrograms per kilogram for egg tissues.  The method's capacity to track fungal toxins across animal tissues and food products reveals the material pathways through which contamination from feed enters human food chains. That the same analytical infrastructure can simultaneously quantify both regulated and emerging toxins suggests how the detection of fungal contamination depends on the prior identification of risk — a classification that shifts with regulatory attention and market pressure rather than with the toxins themselves. The optimization of high-throughput processing reflects the scale at which such contamination must now be monitored to maintain food safety, embedding fungal toxin analysis into routine industrial surveillance of animal agriculture.

title: Unravelling the antifungal mechanism of phytic acid on Aspergillus flavus development and aflatoxin B1 biosynthesis
source: tandf: Food Additives & Contaminants: Part A: Table of Contents
excerpt: Aspergillus flavus (A. flavus) is a plant pathogenic fungus that produces toxic and carcinogenic aflatoxins, posing a threat to food safety and human health. As a kind of food additive, phytic acid (PA) exhibits excellent antimicrobial activity. However, the antifungal effects of PA against A. flavus are not well understood. Here, transcriptomic and biochemical analyses were carried out to investigate the inhibitory effects of PA against A. flavus and potential mechanisms. Our findings demonstrated that PA effectively inhibited the vegetative growth, conidiation and aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) production of A. flavus. In addition, we found that PA also suppressed the pathogenicity of A. flavus on peanut and maize seeds. The transcriptomic analysis confirmed that the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were involved in development, aflatoxin biosynthesis, oxidative stress, ergosterol biosynthesis, and the MAPK signalling pathway in A. flavus. Biochemical experiments further demonstrated that PA could destroy cell membrane integrity and induce reactive oxygen species (ROS) accumulation, eventually resulting in defects of development and AFB1 biosynthesis in A. flavus. Taken together, this research enhances understanding of the antifungal mechanism of PA, and provides novel insights into its potential as a food additive to prevent and control A. flavus contamination.
summary: Phytic acid, a food additive, effectively inhibited the vegetative growth, spore production, and aflatoxin B1 toxin production of *Aspergillus flavus*, a plant pathogenic fungus that contaminates stored crops. Gene expression analysis revealed that phytic acid altered the activity of genes involved in fungal development, toxin biosynthesis, stress response, cell membrane synthesis, and cellular signalling pathways. Biochemical experiments showed that phytic acid damaged the fungal cell membrane and triggered accumulation of reactive oxygen species—unstable oxygen-containing molecules that cause cellular damage—ultimately disrupting both fungal growth and toxin production. The compound also reduced the ability of *Aspergillus flavus* to infect peanut and maize seeds.  Within food storage systems, this research documents a material intervention—phytic acid—that simultaneously acts as a preservative and a stressor. The fungus experiences phytic acid not as a simple poison but as a metabolic disruptor that forces cellular damage and blocks the biosynthetic pathways through which it produces aflatoxins. The same compound that protects stored grain from fungal contamination operates by destabilizing the membrane boundaries and oxidative balance that permit fungal survival, revealing how food safety depends on manipulating the material conditions under which pathogens persist or fail.

title: Concentration of aflatoxin B1 in Iranian rice and human health risk assessment
source: tandf: Food Additives & Contaminants: Part A: Table of Contents
excerpt: Contamination of food products such as rice with mycotoxins, especially aflatoxins (AFs), can endanger human health and cause economic problems. Dietary exposure to aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) is a public health concern, especially in countries where rice is a staple food, due to its carcinogenic, acute, and chronic effects. Therefore, the aim of this study was to determine the occurrence and concentration levels of AFB1 in domestic (Iranian) rice samples. The presence and mean concentration of AFB1 in 70 Iranian rice samples collected from local markets in Tehran, Iran were measured using a competitive ELISA method. Furthermore, a health risk assessment was performed based on estimated daily intake (EDI) of AFB1 from rice consumption, margin of exposure (MOE), and liver cancer risk in Iranian children and adults. AFB1 was detected in 26 samples (37.1%) with the mean concentration levels of 1.86 ± 0.67 ng/g (ranges from 1.12 to 4.26); of these, 7 samples (26.9%) had values exceeding the limit set by European Union regulations (2 ng/g). Additionally, AFB1 contamination in no rice sample exceeded the maximum limit accepted by Iranian National Standardisation Organisation (5 ng/g). This study showed that the mean EDI of AFB1 was 9 and 3 ng/kg bw/day for children and adults, respectively. In addition, the mean MOEs for children and adults were 18 and 64, respectively, indicating a public health concern. In addition, the present study showed that the risks of liver cancer associated with rice consumption among Iranian children and adults were 0.13 and 0.04 cancer cases/year/per 10<sup>5</sup> people, respectively. This study showed that monitoring AFB1 levels in rice is essential for assessing food safety and protecting public health, particularly in developing countries where rice is a staple food.
summary: Aflatoxin B1 contamination was detected in 37.1 percent of 70 rice samples collected from Tehran markets, with mean concentrations of 1.86 nanograms per gram, ranging from 1.12 to 4.26 nanograms per gram. Seven samples exceeded European Union regulatory limits of 2 nanograms per gram, though all samples remained below the 5 nanogram per gram threshold set by Iranian National Standardisation Organisation. This paper measured aflatoxin B1 using competitive enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay and calculated daily intake exposure based on rice consumption patterns, finding mean daily intakes of 9 nanograms per kilogram of body weight for children and 3 nanograms per kilogram of body weight for adults. The margin of exposure—a ratio comparing safe exposure levels to actual intake—was 18 for children and 64 for adults, both indicating potential public health concern. Estimated liver cancer risk from rice consumption was 0.13 cases per year per 100,000 people in children and 0.04 cases per year per 100,000 people in adults.  This paper documents a material entanglement characteristic of food systems in developing economies: the same grain that provides nutritional security simultaneously carries a carcinogenic contaminant whose presence reflects prior exposures during cultivation, storage, and distribution. The regulatory gap between European Union limits and Iranian standards—a twofold difference—reveals how acceptable risk thresholds are negotiated through economic and political channels rather than biological necessity, leaving populations consuming rice as a dietary staple subject to differential protection depending on where safety standards are set. Children's higher estimated daily intake and lower margin of exposure expose the uneven distribution of hazard within households, where dietary staples concentrate exposure among those least able to avoid them.

title: Simultaneous determination and occurrence assessment of 55 mycotoxins in tea and spices using liquid chromatography-high resolution mass spectrometry
excerpt: Multi-mycotoxin occurrence was investigated in samples of teas and spices marketed in Bangkok, Thailand, to protect consumer health. To date, the investigation of mycotoxins in teas and spices has become an important issue worldwide. Therefore, 120 tea samples consisting of 40 samples each of green tea, oolong tea, and black tea, and 300 samples consisting of 30 samples each of black pepper, white pepper, cardamom, coriander seed, cinnamon, cumin, chili powder, nutmeg, star anise, and turmeric powder, were sampled from markets in Bangkok, Thailand. The samples were extracted using a QuEChERS-like (quick, easy, cheap, effective, rugged, safe) approach and the targeted 55 mycotoxins in the tea and spice samples were analyzed using liquid chromatography-high resolution mass spectrometry. The results identified various levels of positive mycotoxin contamination in the tea and spice samples, with a variety of mycotoxins identified. summary: Researchers tested 120 tea samples and 300 spice samples purchased from Bangkok markets for contamination by 55 different mycotoxins—toxic compounds produced by moulds. The samples included three types of tea (green, oolong, and black) and ten types of spices (black pepper, white pepper, cardamom, coriander seed, cinnamon, cumin, chili powder, nutmeg, star anise, and turmeric powder). Using a rapid extraction method followed by liquid chromatography-high resolution mass spectrometry, the researchers detected various mycotoxins across the samples at differing levels. All black pepper and cinnamon samples tested positive for mycotoxin contamination, while black tea samples showed no detectable contamination. Beauvericin, an emerging mycotoxin, was identified among the contaminants, though the abstract ends before reporting complete findings.  The selective contamination pattern across these commodities—universal in some spices, absent in others—reflects the material conditions of their production and trade rather than uniform exposure. Black pepper and cinnamon's consistent contamination suggests particular vulnerabilities in cultivation, drying, or storage that create conditions favourable to mould growth, while the absence of mycotoxins in black tea indicates that processing or sourcing practices can interrupt this pathway. These Bangkok market samples thus document how the same fungal metabolites operate simultaneously as health hazards for consumers and as indicators of labour conditions, agricultural stress, and post-harvest infrastructure—revealing how food safety emerges not as a universal standard but as a patchy outcome of specific material arrangements across supply chains.

title: Occurrence of mycotoxins in pastures and conserved forages in the Southeast region of Brazil
excerpt: This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of mycotoxins in pastures (N = 84) and in conserved hay, haylage, and silage forages (N = 107) collected from 21 farms in the Southeast region of Brazil, using high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS). Mycotoxins were quantified in 94 and 91% of pasture and conserved forage samples, respectively. The most frequently found mycotoxins in pastures were aflatoxins (AFs) and ochratoxin A (OTA). Among the plant species analyzed, Urochloa spp. showed the highest detection rates, especially for T-2 toxin (T-2), AFs, and OTA. Fumonisins (FBs) and zearalenone (ZEN) were the most prevalent mycotoxins in conserved forages. In pastures, OTA had the highest occurrence rate in summer, although FBs were more frequently quantified in the winter. The mean levels of AFs (sum of AFB1 and AFB2) in pastures and conserved forages exceeded the European Union’s maximum tolerance limits for animal feed. Co-occurrence of mycotoxins was observed in 59 and 35 samples of pastures and conserved forages (70 and 34%, respectively). summary: Pastures and conserved forages across 21 farms in the Southeast region of Brazil contained detectable mycotoxins in 94% and 91% of samples respectively, as measured by high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry. Aflatoxins and ochratoxin A dominated pasture contamination, while fumonisins and zearalenone were most prevalent in hay, haylage, and silage. The grass species Urochloa spp. accumulated the highest mycotoxin loads, particularly T-2 toxin, aflatoxins, and ochratoxin A. Seasonal variation was evident: ochratoxin A peaked in summer pastures while fumonisins were more common in winter. Mean aflatoxin levels in both pastures and conserved forages exceeded European Union maximum tolerance limits for animal feed. Multiple mycotoxins co-occurred in 70% of pasture samples and 34% of conserved forage samples, with aflatoxins combined with fumonisins, T-2 toxin, or ochratoxin A forming the most common contamination patterns.  The mycotoxin burden documented in this paper reveals how fungal metabolites become embedded in the material infrastructure of livestock production—pasture grasses and stored feed—across a region. Rather than appearing as discrete contaminants, these toxins accumulate as overlapping chemical assemblages shaped by seasonal moisture and storage conditions, creating simultaneous exposure pathways for grazing and confined animals. The detection of aflatoxins at levels exceeding regulatory thresholds across both fresh and processed forages indicates that contamination persists through preservation methods, suggesting that the economic pressures driving intensified forage production and storage in Brazilian agriculture may systematically distribute fungal toxins through feed chains in ways that current regulatory frameworks do not fully contain.

title: Protective effect of organic selenium and organic chromium dietary supplementation against aflatoxicosis in mice
excerpt: Aflatoxins are highly toxic mycotoxins linked to serious health issues, including hepatotoxicity, immunosuppression, and oxidative stress. This study investigated the protective effects of chromium-methionine (Cr-Met) and selenium-methionine (Se-Met) supplementation, both alone and in combination, against aflatoxin-induced toxicity in mice. Five dietary treatments were implemented: a control diet (T1), an aflatoxin-contaminated diet containing 2 mg of aflatoxins per kg of diet (T2), and aflatoxin-contaminated diets supplemented with 0.5 mg of Cr-Met per kg (T3), 0.5 mg of Se-Met per kg (T4), or a combination of both (T5). Exposure to aflatoxins significantly (p < 0.05) impaired growth performance, disrupted liver enzyme profiles, suppressed immune function, and compromised antioxidant defense mechanisms. In contrast, dietary supplementation with T3 and T4 markedly (p < 0.05) enhanced growth performance, increased feed intake, and elevated immunoglobulin levels while reducing oxidative stress markers and liver damage.
